I started my business five years ago in my own house. Now, I have my own location a few blocks from home. I cook chicken, home-made jueces, tacos, enchiladas y other foods. I have many diners because my place is so clean and my tastful presentation of my dishes. I personally attend to all my customers. \r\n

\r\nI made my first loan a year ago, and now I making a second investment in a second chicken fryer because I now have many more clients. Before, I only opened on the weekends, but now I am open everyday from 11am to 10pm. I decided to work so much more because I was making good profits which I am using to put my children in a good school and I hope to enlarge our house.

column4: I will invest the money in the purchase of a new motor for the machine of my factory since the motor is too old and it is already giving problems.  I Also will invest part of the money to buy materials to make my bread.
column18:
Like two of my brothers, I have been owner of a bakery, it is a familiar tradition for more than 40 years and we have all fought very hard to maintain our businesses, in my case, with the new motor I will be able to increase my production and will fulfill the orders of my clients and I will not have problems to repay the loan because my incomes will increase.\r\n

\r\nBecause all the materials that I use have increased their price, I will use part of the money to buy a great amount of products to obtain discounts and to reduce my costs.

column4: I will invest in the purchase of basic products for the Nicaraguan feeding (Rice, beans, Oil, Salt, Sugar, tortillas, etc.) and in other products that are sold quickly like refreshments and snacks.
column18:
The loan will allow me to manage my goal to turn my Grocery Shop into a basic grain distributor, that will give reputation to my Shop and I will be able to increase my profitsâ€?.\r\n

\r\nDue to my experience as the owner of this Grocery Shop, I consider that the key to success is that the clients prefer me because I have a good inventory, all the products that they need.

column4: Upgrade of three hot dog carts with the addition of new grills to cook carne asada
column18:
My business is called MISTER HOT DOG, and we started by renting two carts together with my wife. After we started to generate some consistent income, we decided to take a loan to buy our own little cart. That is how we started to have our own business, and now we own three carts which are strategicially placed around the city where our customers always ask us for â€œcarne asadaâ€?, a dish which is our â€œplato tipicoâ€? in Honduras. \r\n

\r\nWith our loan, we are going to upgrade the carts with grills to give our customers what they are asking for. In the future, we will offer other new dishes using the grills. Our major expense is our childrenâ€™s education.

column4: Invest in inventory of meats, canned foods, razors, chicken, butter, tiolet paper, beans, sugar, corn, and other Ã­tems.
column18: I have had a grocery for the past 5 years.  I sell everyday household Ã­tems like chicken, sugar, coffee, butter, ham, and the like.  My business is in a good location and my costumers like how I treat them.  My business sustains our family because my husband does not make enough meet the needs of the whole family, so together we are able to provide for ourselves.

column4: Buy beverages, medicines, and other products.
column18: My business is located near the main street of our town Danli, and I have been running it for three years.  My business has grown because of both regular local clients, but also people traveling into town from the country side.  The products that sell the best in my business are beverages, bread, medicine, and milk.

column4: Buy inventory like bread, ham, pens and paper, medicine, juices, and the like.
column18:
I have had my grocery store for three years. We are open all week, and I sell the household Ã­tems used everyday like butter, bread, milk, eggs, and other tasty treats. \r\n

\r\nMy business is widely-known for my kindness and my unforgetable smile! We open early and stay open late, so my whole family works in the store since together we are sending the children to school.

column4: Purchase of inventory: school supplies, flowers, and sweets.
column18: My business is called â€œLinda Nenaâ€? and it is a family businesss.  We sell childrenâ€™s clothes and shoes, as well as flowers, sweets, and other Ã­tems. We have a very strategic location in the city of Tegucigalpa.  Now we do both retail and wholesale business.  Business is good and we need to invest to satisfy our clients.

column4: Buy inventory: cheese, rice, beans, corn.
column18: My business is selling cheese, beans, and corn, which I have been doing for 3 years.  My business has grown and I now distribute product wholesale to groceries, small marketplaces, and to other wholesalers.  I also sell to many of the traditional bakers who make the well-known rosquillas and quesadillas here in the town of Danli.  Due to the quality of my product and my service, demand has risen and I need to invest in inventory.

column4: To invest in inventory such as toys for children, school supplies, snacks, and personal-care products.
column18: My little market is one of the biggest and luckiest in my whole community.  I sell personal-care products and school supplies for children among other Ã­tems.  I have been in business for 13 years, and I have been able to grow my store little by little each time I sell a little more.  Since school is starting, I need to invest in inventory of school supplies like notebooks, pens, and other things.

column4: Invest in inventory like cooking oil, bread, sweets, sardines, and corn flour.
column18: I have been in business for 4 years because my customers perfer the service I provide them and because I have in stock everything they need everyday like milk, sugar, coffee, bread, eggs, cheese, beverages, and many other things.  I am a single mother and I have to work successfully to provide for the needs and education of my son.

column4: Buy flour.
column18: I have been making flour tortillas for three years, and I think of myself as a fighter who has been able to earn the patronage of good customers.  My clients are groceries, market stands, and local neighbors in my community.  I know that with the loan, I can increase sales and profits.  I have two children in school, so I am very motivated to succeed in my daily and weekly sales goals.

column4: Compra de pollo, queso, leche, pan, dulces, papel, espaguetis y otros (Buying chicken, cheese, milk, bread, sweets, paper, spaghetti and others.)
column18: My name is Rafaela, and my business is called Central Supplies, which I have owned and run for 17 years.  I started out selling just ice cream, and then just a few other Ã­tems, slowly growing into this little market I now have.  I sell milk, bread, oil, chicken, cheese and ice cream, and other daily use items.  My business is located on the main street in the main market in the town of Danli, so there are many people that pass by.  They stop into my little market for the delicious treats I make, but then they stay to do their monthly shopping, so that is how I have build my business.

column4: Buy inventory of two clothing loads.
column18: In our town, most people have very few economic resources, so they perfer to buy second-hand clothing.  My business is to sell second-hand clothing imported from the United Status.  I have been running this business for 8 years and I have regular customers.  Thanks to my business, I have been able to build my little house, and now my two children are in school.

column4: Invest in inventory of pants, shirts, and shoes.
column18: My business is located on the main comercial street in the town of Danli, a well-traveled street which allows me to have good monthly sales most months.  The constant traffic is from the near-by bus station where peope are always coming and going, often passing by my shop.  I am married with a two year old daughter, and with my income from the business I can provide good nourishment and medical care for my family.

column4: Invest in inventory of cosmetics, cloths and hand bags.
column18: My business is informal because I do not have my own store, but I do pay my taxes to the town, so I am able to keep my informal spot near the general market in Danli.  I sell cosmetics, chains, flowers, gifts, and other Ã­tems.  I also go directly to Tabacco Companies where most of the employees are women and would be interested in my products.  My wife and I run this business together, together we staff the booth, do the administrative details, and make decisions about what products we will invest in.

column4: Given a loan of USD 150 She will be able to include other varieties of vegetables. This will attract more clients to her business and hence increase her income.
column18:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Sarah is married with 6 children and she is the bread winner. Her last born is disabled and attends special school which is expensive.

She started her business with USD 7.and has since expanded it by ploughing back part of her income. She has attended various business trainings offered by WEEC and this has enabled her to manage her small business.

column4: Given a loan of USD 300 she will be able to add to her stock. This will enable her supply the Pishori rice to the adjacent Langata area where she has started getting orders from.
column18:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Margaret is a single lady with two children. She has educated them up to secondary school. Though they have not gotten formal jobs. She has assisted them get into the Jua Kali (informal) sector where they work as Mechanics.

Margaret has been in the Jua Kali sector for the last 15 years. Her experience has made her to be very keen in studying the market trends. She therefore engages in goods that are on high demand. Currently she is engaged in selling Pishori rice. She takes her orders from retail shops, households, festivities like weddings. She joined WEEC programme in 2005. She got a loan of USD 139 and bought more stock. She paid her loan in 10 months.

column4: Given a loan of USD 150 she will be able to pay school fees for her daughter and limit withdrawals from her business. This will enable the business to grow and be self sustainable.
column18:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Sarah has been involved in community Work both in her local church as a Sunday school teacher and also at village level as a youth counselor. This has enabled her to know many parents in the area.

Her business idea stemmed from the plight of many working parents who have had problems getting house girls who are honest. She therefore decided to start a day care centre. She Charges USD 7 per child per month. The income she gets from her work is enough to pay the room she has rented and also cater for the household expenses. In 2004 She took a loan of USD 139 that enabled her to go for a nursery school course. The course was to prepare her for her new business. In year 2005 She took another loan of USD 139 that enabled her set her business.

column4: If a loan of USD 700 is granted, she will put up 3 more permanent rooms since there is high demand of rental houses in Ongata Rongai.
column18:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Loyce is a widow with 3 children and 5 dependants. She is a trained nursery school teacher. Through her training she has learnt to be disciplined and committed to her work. She is involved in church activities as a deacon and also the Chairlady of the womenâ€™s guild in the church.

Her preference of real estate (rental rooms) is because it does not take a lot of her time. She started her small project of 6 semi permanent rooms. From her rental income and loans she was able to put up 12 permanent rooms. She does not use her loans in any other way other than in her said project. To date she has 78 rental rooms. Her business has enabled her to bring up her family and also pay school fees for the five children who had previously dropped out of school for lack of school fees.

column4: Given a loan of USD 300 she will be able to complete the two rooms and install electricity to make them more marketable.
column18:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Naomi is a single mother with 5 children and 2 dependants. Naomi is an active member in the community. She is the Coordinator of the umoja road village. She is a leader of the Nambala Women group that has a project of grinding mill.

By joining the women groups in Ongata Rongai Naomi was able to attend short business skills courses. She has experience in different businesses from which she was able to raise capital buy a plot and developed it with rental houses due to high demand. She has 6 semi permanent houses and two are due for completion. She took a loan from WEEC of USD 139 in 2005 and laid the foundation of the two rooms.

column4: She would like to buy another cow and a water tank to store enough water for her cows for such a season.
column18:
This business is a member of the Kadisi Wisdom Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Jacinta is 43 years old, married with 4 children. She is involved in community work where she takes care of destitute children in the locality by giving free education in her private school.

Jacinta is a dairy farmer in Ongata Rongai. Currently, she has one dairy cow which earns her USD. 100 per month. This has been a reduction due to the prolonged dry season in that area. Under normal climatic conditions, she is able to raise 3 dairy cows and these can give her USD.456 per month. This enables her to take care of her family.

column4: Restocking his store with the most popular types of bread.
column18: Iâ€™m an itinerant bread salesman.  Twice a week I go to Tegucigalpa and buy my bread supply for the week directly from the bakeries.  Upon returning to my community I travel in my car throughout my neighbouring villages selling the bread. Iâ€™ve had my business for three years and in this time my clientele has increased significantly, particularly with small grocers. At the moment I do not have enough capital to cover the demand that I have.

column4: Sale of various popular pharmaceuticals
column18: Iâ€™ve been selling medicines itinerantly in neighbouring communities for the past year.   This business generates earnings that I use to provide for my family. I also sell low quality wood that I buy from sawmills. This wood is used as a substitute for electricity by the people the in my residence.

column4: Buying rice, lard, beans and dairy products.
column18: My family and I serve food for a living.  I have a diner where I serve traditional food.  Throughout time I have attracted many clients to my establishment.   Many people visit my business each day because it is located in front of a bus terminal. At this moment the demand for food is very high that is why I need larger credits to cover the costs of serving more clients.

column4: Repair vehicle.
column18: I provide transportation for people travelling from the city of El Paraiso to Las Manos in the border between Nicaragua and Honduras.  Iâ€™ve been doing this for the past seven years.  I make the journey on a daily basis, so I need to take my van to the mechanic for a check up and restore the seats in order to improve the security and comfort of my passengers.

column4: Buying films, batteries and glass for the studio
column18: Iâ€™ve had my business for the past 5 years, I take photos in special events, frame photos and diplomas, sell film and cameras as well as well as car batteries.  My business has grown parallel with my improved experience and my knowledge of camera repairs. I also fix cameras but only on few occasions. I only have basic repair equipment and would need greater financing in order to improve my shop and my services.

column4: Buying shoes, blouses for women and girls, sock, menâ€™s undergarments amongst others.
column18: For the past 4 years Iâ€™ve dedicated myself to the sale of clothing and shoes for children, women and men. I sell my products to various offices in this city.  I already have a set clientele and I get paid every 15 days or upon delivery. I also sell from my residence with the help of my kids.  This business generates some earnings that allow me to better provide for my household.

column4: Buying corn, banana leafs, raisins, potatoes, lard, string and condiments
column18: My name is Santos Casco and I make and sell delicious nacatamelas, one of our typical foods.  In the last months my business has grown since I have received many more orders.  My business clients say that the flavour of my nacatamales is unique which is made better by my kind, charming customer service.  I also sell my nacatamales to my neighbours.

column4: Buying flower, lard, condiments and firewood.
column18: I bake and sell bread (rosquillas and quesadillas) and receive orders from my clients, housewives or owners of small grocery shops. I have done this for the past three years and with the help of one of my sons Iâ€™ve managed to grow significantly.  My demand is now so large that I need to buy more ingredients.

column4: Buying an electric mill
column18: My name is Dirminda Sorto, I am the owner of a mill that grinds corn for household production and consumption of tortillas. Iâ€™ve had my mill for the past 13 years, and since itâ€™s the only mill in my community I have a lot of clients, therefore it has deteriorated.  The mill is one of the primary income sources of my family. I would like a credit in order to buy an electric mill and be able to continue with my business. Also, during school session, I sell candy to the students in my community and at the entrance of the school.

column4: Buying lard, soap, candies, cookies, soda, bread and gum
column18: I am the owner of a small grocery shop that sells basic staples and other popular products such as milk, bread, lard, soda, candies amongst others. Iâ€™ve had my business for the past two years and itâ€™s the only shop in my community. Because of this I have a high demand and I need to restock with products that will be easily sold. I use the earnings from my store in order to keep my children in primary and secondary school.

column4: Buying wood, nails, glue, varnish amongst others
column18: I am the owner of a carpentry shop that builds beds, doors, wardrobes, dinning tables, chairs amongst others. I have lots of clients and most of my work is done by order.  I get paid 50% when we sign the contract and 50% when I hand them the final product, which makes it harder for me to sell furniture to other clients. This area has lots of demand for the elaboration of furniture and wood therefore I decided to work with PRISMA.

column4: Buying bread, candy, corn flakes, milk, spaghetti, sauce, salt, corn flour, medicines, etc.
column18: Iâ€™ve had my shop for the past seven years. Iâ€™ve managed to administer it and increase my number of clients.  It is my only source of income so I take care of my sales. I am a single mother of two. One of my sons is in school and the other is two years old. I think if I invest more capital in restocking my store Iâ€™ll get more earnings

column4: Buying cloth, zippers, buttons and lace
column18: My name is Angelina LÃ³pez and I sell accessories for sewing;  I also tailor clothing for women.  Iâ€™ve been tailoring for the past fifteen years and selling the accessories for the past two. I need the credit in order to buy the necessary cloth to make school uniforms.

column4: Buying dyes, nail treatments, nail polish and a hair drier
column18: I've had my business for two years.  Before my salon I worked for a private company and when I retired I invested the money in my own business. At the moment Iâ€™m working towards getting more clients and in order to do so I need to get good quality products to satisfy them.  The earnings of the salon help me with my family.

column4: Buying fruits, vegetables, sugar, soda amongst others.
column18: Both my husband and myself run the business.  We both keep the store that generates income that covers the expenses of my family. My business is one of the largest in my community and once in a while visitors ask me to cook for them, which provides some extra earnings.

column4: Buying Panadol (aka Tylenol), Vicks cough drops, Mentolina, Ibuprodol, Alicol, Sal Andrew, Alcohol, amongst others.
column18: I sell popular medicines for headache, diarrhea, fleas, stomach aches amongst others.  I sell my product in neighbouring communities. My wife and my two sons sell the medicine from my house. Iâ€™ve had this business for the past two years.  My wife also sells products from catalogues. The main source of income in my household is the medicines.

column4: Buying sodas, common medicine, sugar, lard, soap, oil, bread, broth amongst others.
column18: For the past 5 years Iâ€™ve had my store. I have a lot of clients because of the great diversity of products that I offer.  Iâ€™m located at the exit of the city and because of this I get a lot of business from the people travelling to the surrounding villages.  They buy their weekly provisions in my store. One way in which Iâ€™ve increased my sales is by allowing customers to pay every 15 days rather than on a weekly basis.

column4: Maintenance of the taxi
column18: I own two car that I use as a taxis to provide tranportation in the city of Danily.  I work from 6:00 am â€“ 7:30 pm therefore I have to give maintenance to both my cars. I need to keep using at least one in order to retian my daily earnings.  I also need to change  the tires in the other.  In my family we are four, two kids, my wife and myself.  I mainly use the income for our everyday life.

column18: I sell clothing and shoes for children, men and women.  My business is in  one of the main streets of Danili.  Iâ€™ve had my stand for the past two years and my sales are good given that my main clients are people from other communities that visit Danili.

column4: To purchase a barber's chair, scissors, and other equipment
To Purchase Cloth

Given a loan of USD 700, she will be able to buy a water pump to facilitate her vegetable farming and meet the high demand.\r\nShe will  be able to add more poultry stock and meet the demand from her clients and get new customers.
column18:
This business is a member of the Melody Mothers group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lucy is a widow with one dependant. Despite being a widow she is very active.

Lucy grows and sells vegetables and poultry farming on a small plot. She started her farming business with a loan of USD 280. She sells her vegetable products to the neighbors and the nearby markets. Due to the prolonged dry spells, the demand for her products has increased since she is among the few using irrigation method of farming.

For poultry, she gets orders from hotels in Nairobi though due to lack of enough capital she is not able to meet the demand from her clients.

column4: She intends to open up a milk collecting centre after being given a loan of USD 1000. This will enable her buy a freezer for her milk to serve customers better.
column18:
This business is a member of the Melody Mothers group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Mary Kunyua is married with 3 dependants. She is involved in community work and takes care of the orphans in her locality.

Mary sales fresh milk from her own cows and also buys from farmers in the same area. She distributes it to hotels in Nairobi. The income from her business is basically used in expansion of her business and feeding the orphans. Lack of a permanent stall for her business has been a major challenge since new customers canâ€™t locate her.

column4: The loan applied for will be used for re-stocking the shop to catch up with the demand in the area.
column18:
Elizabeth is single and an active member of Kandisi Wisdom Women Group. She has been a member of Women Fighting Aids in Kenya (WOFAK) since 2003.She trains the youth in HIV/AIDS related matter to minimize the spread of this scourge.

She has a small retail shop where he sells phone accessories, and operates a payphone. As a trainer with WOFAK, she is given an allowance of USD.4 per day 3 days a week. Late last year, she had her business in Nairobi unfortunately; thieves broke into her shop and cleaned it.

column4: The loan applied for of USD 300 will be used to buy more materials thus increase capacity to supply all orders received. This will increase her income and improve her standard of living.
column18:
Ruth is the Chairlady of Kandisi Wisdom Womenâ€™s Group. She is married with 4 children.

She is in the business of screen printing with the husband. They have been able to buy a plot of land on which their permanent house is and can afford to send their children to school. Currently, her business is housed in her residence and intends to rent a shop in the town centre to increase her clientele.

column4: Given the loan of USD.1100 She will purchase a wood curving machine and increase the stock of timbers.
column18:
Teresia is married with 6 dependants. She is a very active lady and a treasurer of Ole Roimen Women Group.

Teresia is the sole supplier of Furniture in her locality. She gets orders from the schools and residents since she does quality work. Though she is not able to meet the demand of her clients on time due to limited capital and lack of wood curving machine. \r\nIn addition to the furniture business, she sells vegetables and milk from her zero grazed cows. Her income from farming is steady throughout the year.

column4: As a result of increased clientele, she is to increase her stock and rent a stall for her business. Given a loan of USD.300 she will be in position of increasing her stock and serve her clients well. This will improve her sales as well as her income.
column18:
Nelly is married with 5 dependants. She takes care of the whole family, the husband has a poor paying job.

Nelly sells used clothes and her stock is USD 100.She does not have a permanent stall as it is expensive to own one for the time being. Her business is not enough to cater for her family basic needs and education.

column4: Increase inventory
column18: Marcos is a single father who owns a small store that sells chickens and other meats. He averages about 16 hours of work a day and depends on his family to take care of his daughter. With the money received from the loan Marcos plans to increase his inventory so that he can diversify his products and buy in bulk at lower prices. He plans to use the increased income to provide better health care, education and clothing for his daughter.

column4: Increase inventory
column18: Walter is originally from ManabÃ­ but has lived in Guayaquil for 15 years. He owns a small store where he sells groceries and other food items. He learned the business from his parents who provide some support for him but cannot give him credit. His wife also helps out at the store, but in order to grow he needs a source of capital other than the loan sharks. With the credit he plans to increase and diversify his inventory. Currently his profits average about two dollars a day.

column4: Increase inventory
column18: Don Melecio is a tailor who produces menâ€™s suits and other clothing. He has 6 children who he cares for all by himself because of a wife that abandoned the family. His dream is to support his children so that they may receive a college education that will help them make a better life from themselves. Although he has over 25 years of experience the lack of capital does not allow him to produce at higher quantities. He is terrified of the loan sharks but is confident he can handle the loans.

column4: Increase inventory in time for Carnival
column18: Luz owns a store that sells school, office and party supplies. She is a single mother of one child who is currently still in school. She mainly sells notebooks, pens and party items for children and adults. The loans will help Luz purchase increased volume of products in times when demand is high such as carnival, Christmas and other holidays. She has over 25 years of experience in this business.

column4: increase inventory
column18: Vicente owns a shop in his house where he sells shoes and other sports equipments. He and his wife manage the store while taking care of their only son. He is in need of capital in order to be able to access better and more attractive styles for his client base. He will use the capital to try out different vendors of apparel and purchase products at higher quantities.

column4: Increase inventory
column18: Rogelio owns his business on the outskirts of Guayaquil, but his neighborhood has many people that are potential clients. He has 3 children and a wife who helps out in their store whenever necessary. Rogelio has 5 years of experience in the business but needs capital in order to buy from wholesalers at cheaper prices. He also states that he will use new capital to invest in products that are in high demand at his store but he cannot currently afford. Rogelio says loan sharks charge above 20% interest and he cannot afford to repay those loans.

column4: Increase inventory and add stock variety
column18: IsaÃ­as owns a store where he sells items of first necessity such as food and hygienic products. He is 46 years old and has 4 children. His business is well placed in a corner and is accredited by the government but IsaÃ­as does not have access to credit. With increased capital he plans to add variety and volume to his inventory in order to increase sales and profits. He also seeks to add an employee who may be able to help him in his sotre. He wants to use the money he makesto provide a better education for his four children.

column4: Increase inventory
column18: Francisco is 48 years old and owns a shop for veterinary and agricultural products. He provides foods and medicines for domestic and farm animals in the neighborhood. He has over 25 years of experience in this business and is seeking loans in order to acquire better quality and higher quantity of products so that he may serve his clients better. He comments that the only access to credit he has charges 10% to 20% monthly interest and is way beyond what he can afford. He hope he can use profits made from his business in order to provide a better living for his two children who he cares for by himself.

column4: Increase inventory
column18: Carmen has lived in Guayaquil for over twenty years where she owns a small grocery store. She is a widow with three children that she cares for by herself. She lives in a remote area of Guayaquil but she knows her business well as she has over 13 years of experience. With the loan she will be able to purchase products in bulk and lower costs.

column4: Invest in tools
column18: Martha owns a small stand that sells chickens to the public. She learned the business from her parents and has been in this line of work for over 15 years. Although she earns money from this business and her husband has a humble but stable salary they are often short of money and do not have enough to invest in her business. With the loan money Martha plans to invest in more products and better tools. Currently she begins work at 6 a.m. and usually dedicates 16 hours a day to her business.

column4: Buy a lathe machine
column18: My business consists of the reparation of parts for agricultural vehicles and machinery, lathes and everything related to lathes. I have 8 years of experience and regular clients that supply parts from various shops in the community and from surrounding communities. I need this loan to complete the purchase of a lathe machine now that I enough have jobs and with a single machine it is difficult to complete all the orders quickly. The parts will also be useful for increasing sales.

column4: Purchase of a larger assortment of clothes for women, men and children as well as school and dress shoes.
column18: For 5 years my business has sold clothing and shoes for women, men and children, distributing the merchandise door-to-door among my neighbors and friends that prefer to do business with me at the moment because I offer them affordable prices with methods of payment. I also have clients who are teachers and factory workers and I visit some villages around Danli. Maintaining good clients and administration has generated a good income for me, but I need the loan to improve my business and cover the costs of labor.

column4: To buy TVs, stereo equiptment, blenders and toasters.
column18: My business sells electronics such as: TVs, irons, video recorders, microwaves, etc. I use the money to help pay for the education of my family and to improve the conditions of the business so that there is always an assortment of products. My business relies/benefits from a good location and regular clients that come to me for their purchases. I need the loan to offer more products that are requested by clients.

column4: To buy toner, paper, staples, folders, clips, pencils, etc.
column18: I have had my business for 12 years, maintaining good clientele and management. My best clients are students, lawyers and some offices. The money I have made through my business has helped me to improve the business and cover family expenses.

column4: To buy shirts, blouses, shoes, socks, etc
column18: My name is Karla Aguilar and I have a business selling clothing, shoes, and cosmetics door-to-door and by request for 5 years. I visit government offices, private companies, my largest buyers being teachers in urban and rural schools and employees of different institutions. I am requesting this loan in order to buy school clothes to increase my sales. With this money I can pay family and educational expenses.

column4: To buy notebooks, pencils, markers, printer ink, printer paper and posterboard.
column18: For 4 years my business has sold paper and office supplies. I decided to become independent and run my own business in order to cover family expenses. I have a good location and the preference of clients who can find a complete assortment of paper and supplies. For this school year I want to sell more school supplies and for this I need the loan to provide a complete assortment.

column4: To buy tools and materials.
column18: I have had my business for 10 years and I am dedicated to repairing electronics Duch as TVs, stoves, DVD players, toasters, and others. I have good clients that provide me with work. Currently I have 2 helpers in my shop. The gains are considerable as they help me to have my business and maintain my home.

column4: To buy 2 bundles of assorted clothing.
column18: I have been selling assorted second-hand clothing for 17 years. In this area there are many similar businesses but the important thing is to have a greater variety of clothing than the competition and that it be of higher quality. Thanks to the profits from my business I can look after the health and education of my children.

column4: Investment in equipment and renovations to shop (shown in photo)
column18:
Angel is a 29-year-old resident of Sliven, Bulgaria. Angel is a member of the Roma minority, also referred to as gypsies. He lives in the Roma neighborhood in a small, 2-room house without running water with his mother and brother.

For the past 15 years, Angel has worked in a bike shop in the center of Sliven tuning and repairing bikes. This year, Angel wants to start his own bike repair shop in the Roma neighborhood, "Nedeshda". Bikes play an important role for transport for members of the Roma community for two key reasons: 1) very few Roma own functioning vehicles and 2) public transport does not serve the Nedeshda. As such, the Roma without donkeys predominately get around by riding their bikes and walking.

The focus of Angel's business will be fixing punctured tires and tubes, broken chains and petals. The seed capital provided by this loan will be enough to cover the equipment he needs (welding tools, wrenches, screwdrivers, saws, hammers and a number of bike-specific tools), inventory (rubber, spare parts) and the modest renovation he needs to perform on the part of his house where he will have this shop (shown in photo).

column4: Purchase of commodities & weighing scale
column18:
Monica A. is a very active member of Life in Africa who came to Kampala as a result of the war in Northern Uganda.

Monica's husband was seriously wounded by rebels before they came to Kampala. He survived his wounds but has been left permanently disabled and unable to do physical work. Monica made ends meet making paper beads from glue and recycled paper, and working in a stone quarry next to the Internally Displaced camp in the outskirts of Kampala where they live.

In August of 2005 Monica joined Life in Africa and now earns a good living making solidarity bracelets that raise global awareness of the situation in Northern Uganda. She employs others to work at her place in the quarry, and finally has enough income to maintain her family's basic needs. She now has enough income to service a small loan of shs. 800,000 ($475), with which she plans help her husband participate in supporting the family again.

They have a small room at their residence which Monica and her husband plan on turning into a food shop. Her husband will run the shop while Monica continues to work.

Below is her budget; Sugar 3 bags @ 70,000/= 210,000/=
Maize flour 3 bags @ 50,000/= 100,000/=
Peanuts 1 bags @ 150,000/= 150,000/=
Soap 2 boxes@ 15,000/= 30,000/=
Cooking Oil 1 j/can@ 30,000/= 30,000/=
Simsim 1 bag @ 150,000/= 150,000/=
Weighing Scale 1 pc @ 70,000/= 70,000/=
Transport 50,000/=
Contingencies 10,000/=

Based on her current income, she will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. Monica has desig-nated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu, her wartorn home.

column4: Installation of water tap & water company fees
column18:
Ocola J. is 52 years old and is married with 5 children. He is Acholi and is one of the many thousands of people who were forced to flee their homes in the North because of the war that has been going on for the last 20 years. His family lives in an Internally Displaced People's camp in the outskirts of Kampala called the Acholi Quarter. Six months ago J. joined Life in Africa and has been an active member ever since. He started as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project but his hard work and determination quickly earned him a promotion to a sanding processor.

He has acquired a piece of land from the King of Buganda who has sympathy for the people of Acholi and who has set aside free land for them. Knowing that the people of the Acholi quarter have to go long distances to look for water, he has a plan to install a water tap on his land. The current water sellers who bring water in to this hilltop area are charging five shillings per litre for water which makes it very hard for the people to purchase water for their needs. With a water tap installed on his land, J. will be able to purchase water for only one shilling per litre and he plans on selling this water for a reduced rate of 3 shillings per litre to his community.

Not only will this provide a steady income for his family needs, but it will also offer a valuable service to his community at a more affordable price than they can currently get. This will insure that he has a secure source of buyers for his water, and it is likely to have a great impact on those living in the Acholi quarters.

To accomplish this project, J. is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475). He es-timates that once he acquires this loan it will take approximately one week to have the water tap installed. Below is his budget:

16 metal pipes @ 12000= each =192000=
connection fee to national water=300000=
labor charges & other expenses =200000=
building of small house so that the tap can be locked to avoid theft =100000=
The whole total is 792000=.

Based on his current income, J. will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. J. loves music and dance, and has designated the community impact portion of the interest he pays to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery program.

column4: Purchase of fridge, additional packing & raw materials
column18:
Grace A. is a mother of four children and has been an active member of Life in Africa for the last four years. Five years ago she was faced with the problem of earning enough money to support herself and her children. As with many women in her situation, she turned to something she knew to try and earn money. She happened to know how to make good peanut butter and so she started her small business. Her main goal was to be self reliant and to serve her customers well while earning an income to support her children.

In the beginning she used the age old method of grinding the nuts using a mortar and pestle. This method worked but it was a very slow process and she found she was not able to make the peanut butter fast enough to earn adequate money. To remedy this, she carefully planned and saved to purchase a processing machine. This enabled her to process enough to meet the de-mands of her customers and her business grew.

But her good business sense tells her that she can do more. She now has the capability of pro-ducing large quantities but still must produce smaller batches because she has no way of storing it until it is sold. This will require the purchase of a refrigerator which will allow her to always have a supply on hand and will also enable her to increase her number of customers. To accomplish this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us. This amount will purchase a refrigerator, additional packing materials needed and the necessary capital to expand her production. Below is her budget:

800,000/= LOAN BUDGET
FRIDGE 400,000=
PACKING MATERIALS 200,000=
ADDITIONAL CAPITAL 200,000=
TOTAL 800,000=

Based on her current income, Grace will be able to repay the loan in 6 months. She has desig-nated 1/4 of the interest she pays on this loan to support educational opportunities for Life in Af-rica member children.

column4: plastering
column18:
Zarina A. is a widow with three children. When her husband died unexpectedly she had just given birth to the third child and she was left with the sole responsibility of providing for herself and her children. This is no easy task for a woman in Uganda but Zarina was determined and remarkably managed to obtain a job as a housekeeper in Kampala. It was through this job that she was introduced to Life in Africa and she has been an active member for the last five years.

Zarina saw value in building rental properties as a way to provide for her children's education. She managed to secure several loans through Life in Africa and built a solid housing unit in a poor section of Kampala. She has several tenants living in her property now and she was able to responsibly pay back all her loans. She earns an income from this property of shs. 200,000 ($111) each month. But the house is not yet plastered. She wants to finish the outside properly now to ensure that her tenants have quality housing for their families and to insure the value and durability of her investment.

Zarina is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475) to complete the plastering of the property. Her budget is listed below.

20 bags of cement @ 17000= 340000=
sand 80000=
labor 300000=
transport 50000=
other expenses 30000=
Total 800000=

Based on her current income, Zarina will be able to pay off this loan in 4 months. She has desig-nated 1/4 of the interest she pays to support craft skills development workshops at Life in Africa, which she enjoys taking part in.

column4: building materials
column18:
Peter has just been promoted to Foreman at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. His hope is to eventually return to University for further studies, but in Peterâ€™s family itâ€™s become urgent that he starts to think about finding a wife â€“ two of his younger brothers have serious girlfriends they would like to marry, but it is against custom for them to marry before their older brothers do. With his recent promotion, Peter also believes itâ€™s time he started to think seriously about his future, and a wife is definitely part of the plan.

In Uganda, however, marriage is not a day long event but a long process that begins at the point Peter finds himself now. Since itâ€™s taboo for any girl Peter brings home to enter his fatherâ€™s house, the first thing that must happen is that Peter builds a house of his own on his fatherâ€™s land in Tororo (Eastern Uganda). Peter has been saving for this purpose and would like a loan of shs. 800,000 ($475) to add to what he has saved and complete the house quickly.

Peter is an extremely sincere, hardworking and capable young man, and very popular with the Life in Africa members - who are all now wondering who his choice of bride will be!

Below is Peterâ€™s budget:
Cement 20 Bags @ 17000 = 52000
Sand 2 Trips @ 30000 = 60000
Doors 4 @ 50000 = 200000
Windows 4 @ 15000 = 60000
Nails 4kg @ 4000 = 16000

Based on his current income, Peter will be able to repay this loan in 8 months. He has designated a portion of the interest he pays on the loan to support Life in Africaâ€™s Internet4change Program.

column4: purchase building materials
column18:
Nighty A. is one of the most active Life in Africa member from the displaced Acholi quarter in the ouskirts of Kampala. In addition to working in a stone quarry, she also now earns a part time income making solidarity bracelets to increase awareness of the war in her home of Northern Uganda.

Nighty's husband has deserted her but she has struggled for the welfare of her family. She has managed singlehandedly to send all her children back to school and has also managed to save a little bit for further development.

With this savings she has acquired a small piece of land at the acholi quarters , where she now plans to build a two roomed house that will create more space for the children.

Below is her budget in full:
Bricks 5,000/= @ 60/= 300,000/=
Cement 10 bags @18,000/= 180,000/=
Iron sheets 20 pcs @10,000/= 200,000/=
Timbers 20 pcs @ 5,000/= 100,000/=
Transport 20,000/=v Total 800,000/=

Based on her current income, Nighty will be able to repy this loan in 12 months. She has desig-nated a 1/4 of the interest she pays on this loan to support educational opportunities for Life in Af-rica member children.

column4: Purchase building materials
column18:
Teopista joined Life in Africa in February of 2005. Since then she has been a very active member and has become a leader at the WE Center. She is a single mother raising three children and she always works very hard to provide for them and to keep them in school. As they get older, the school fees increase and she is looking for a way to insure that she will be able to pay all the fees so they can complete their education. She does not think that being a single mother should be a barrier to her children's education.

Even with all the demands for their needs, she has managed to save enough money to acquire a plot of land. She plans to build a house on this land that she will rent out. The income from this rental property will be specifically used for her children's education. Housing is in high demand so this will be a sound investment.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475) to assist her in starting the first phase of her project. She has savings that she will add to this loan to purchase the necessary materials to lay the foundation and build part of the walls.

Her total project budget is shs. 3,252,000/=
With the 800,000/= that Teopista is asking to borrow for the first phase, she plans to buy:
Bricks 7,000 @ 60/= 420,000/=
Cement 20 bags @ 18,000/= 360,000/=
Transport 20,000/=
TOTAL 780,000/=

Based on her current income, Teopista will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. She has des-ignated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change training program.

column4: Purchase building materials
column18:
Monica is an awesome lady. She is a widowed mother of three beautiful children. She joined Life in Africa in 2003 and is now the WE Center Manager. She is loved and respected by all who work with her.

5 years ago, Monica's husband died of injuries he suffered in a trucking accident. After he died, his family came and claimed all his property, including their family home, leaving Monica and her children left on the street to start life over from scratch. This sort of thing happens far too often in Uganda and there was nothing legal that Monica could do. When she found her way to Life in Af-rica she was destitute, but realized that she could learn new skills that might improve her situation.

Monica learned quickly and worked hard. She is now the Manager of the Life in Africa WE Center and earns a steady income. Her children are all in school and their lives have greatly improved. But they still have no home to call their own, and this is a painful memory for the whole family. Monica feels it's important to give her children a home that no one can take away from them or evict them from.

She has sold some property her family owned in her village and has managed to buy a plot of land in Kireka on the outskirts of Kampala. Here she plans to build a solid family home. She has carefully planned and the project will be completed in three years using money she saves from her salary and a series of loans. The total budget for the house she wishes to build is shs. 13,000,000 ($7220).

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs 800,000 ($475) for the first phase. This will build the foundation of the house. Once this loan is repaid, she will start on the next phase and continue until the house is built. The loan she is requesting will enable her to buy: hard core stones, bricks, sand, and cement, all for laying the foundation of the house.

Based on her current income, Monica can repay this loan in 12 months. She has designated 1/4 of the interest she pays on her loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change training program.

column4: Purchase of materials such as cement, sand, and gravel.
column18: My name is Tulio Morales, my business is the making and selling of cement blocks.  My operation is located on my property where I live, near the town of La Entrada a Copn.  We live in an area where there are a lot of cement shops like mine.  Right now, I have several good orders from people that live in neighboring townships, people who have their own construction businesses.  Peolple come to me for my good quality and fair price.  I have four children of school age, so I work hard to have a good businesss.

column4: Buy inventory: furniture and other household Ã­tems.
column18: My name is Dionicia B., and I have been selling furniture out of my home for ten years.  I buy my inventory in Honduras comercial center, the city of San Pedro Sula.  My store was nothing when it started, now it is the biggest furniture store in my area, I have very good clients and people know me.  I have three children of school age and I know I have to keep my business prosperous in order to provide an educated life for my family.

column4: She plans to buy 4 steers, rear them for some few months and sell. She says the current season is good for them as there is enough pasture.
column18:
This business is a member of Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Joyce is an active member of Enkakenya Women Group which started five years ago. She is married with two children not yet ready for school.

Joyce attended WEECâ€™s livestock programme training and later was given a livestock loan. She has managed to pay it back. Meanwhile, she has been saving small money with the group and this has made her qualify for yet another loan.

column4: She wants to buy a diary cow to at least be getting daily income from the sale of milk.
column18:
This business is a member of the Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Mokoine is married and a mother of four. She is an active member of Enkakenya where she is the rules controller. She is disciplined and hardworking.

Traditionally, she is a Masai and these are cattle keepers. She joined the group five years ago and has been saving with the group for all this time. She attended livestock training and thereafter was given a loan of USD.300. She bought three steers which she later sold and a profit of USD.150. Currently, she is raising four steers hopefully they will be sold in two months time. There is ready market for them in Nairobi and nearby towns.

column4: They plan to improve the type of feeds to counter natural disasters. Therefore, this loan will enable them to buy the improved feeds and buy more steers.
column18:
This business is a member of Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Patricia is an active member of Naretoi Women Group. She is married with 3 children.

Patricia received her first loan from WEEC of USD.300 in 2001. She bought two steers and started her business of making handicraft at home, selling them in Isinya. She then received a loan of USD.600 and bought 4 more steers. To date, she has over 20 steers. She able to pay her children school fees and meet all family requirements. The demand for steers is very high because this area was hit by prolonged drought which forced some cattle keepers to relocate.

column4: She plans to maintain stock at a level of 10 steers to match with the demand in the area. This loan will be used to buy more steers.
column18:
This business is a member of Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Grace is married with 6 dependants. She was educated up to college school level and an adult education teacher in Isinya. She is the current group treasurer and merry go round in the area. She is a member of Mothers Union where she is the treasurer.

Grace started her business of rearing steers in 1996. She received her first loan from WEEC of USD.450 in 2001. She added 6 more steers. In November 2001 she was given another loan of USD.600 which enabled her to buy 8 more steers. These replaced the six which were sold.

column4: The amount requested for will assist her to boost her business such that she maintains and possibly add new clients.
column18:
This business is a member of Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

She is an active lady and has experiences in various businesses such bead work. Hellen is married with four children.

Hellen joined WEEC in year 2001, received a loan of USD300. She started buying and selling Goats and sheep. The business went on well, paid up the first loan and there after, applied for a second loan. She was given a loan of USD.450 which she used to add more stock. She is unable to supply the required number to customers thus a need for more funding to increase stock.

column4: Given USD 450, Joyce will be able to purchase 3 steers and rear them for the market. She will also buy feeds and also graze them in her land now that the rains has come.
column18:
This business is a member of Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Joyce is married with 3 children. She was educated up to primary school level. She was later trained on livestock management. This enabled her to work on improving the cattle for marketing. She is also a devoted member of catholic church.

Traditionally the family has always kept cattle because it has a large area for grazing. Instead of keeping large herds of cattle, Joyce has turned to purchasing of good quality steers and rearing them for 6 months using modern improved methods. She later market the steers at Enkirgirri market at USD 205. Currently Joyce has only 3 steers out of 5 as two died out of prolonged drought.

column4: She intends to buy 6 steers restock her farm to be ready for the season in July when the demand is very high.
column18:
This business is a member of the Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

She is married with 5 children. Family owns grazing land. She has acquired business training from WEEC and also attends business forums organized to train on livestock management; she is able to keep livestock records and all business records.

In year 2003, Lucy took USD 441 and bought 3 steers. WEEC organized for training on livestock management for the clients. Since then Lucy has taken up a USD 588 loan and used the amount for buying 4 steers of which she later sold them at USD 883 after. Lucy is now capable of keeping a number of steers due to the trainings she has had modern livestock management.

column4: If a loan of USD.900 is given to her, she will be in a position to buy two more Dairy cows and a steer, thus increasing milk production as well as income.
column18: Masompa is married with six dependants .she did not have formal education though she was able to educate her children by keeping dairy cows. She is a devoted   Christian and a member of Ack church Mothers Union. She is the chairlady of the group.\r\n\r\nShe started by buying two dairy cows when given a Mifugo loan by WEEC in 2001.she later started Zero grazing. Today her Dairy cows produce enough milk to be consumed at home and twenty litres to be sold to local hotels. Her Dairy farming business enables her to educate her children.

column4: Lucy intends to install electricity in her rental houses. She views this as one of the ways to increase her income, as tenants will be paying much more than before.
column18:
This business is a member of Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lucy W. is a client of WEEC and a member of Queen Esther Women Group. She is a widow who has been self independent for some years. She lives in Ole Roimen where her business is located. She is a mother and a grandmother to several off springs.

Lucy is a successful business woman with rental houses which bring for her a substantial amount of income. Apart from this she is a farmer who rears goat and also cultivates food crops.

With various loans that have been advanced to her by the group and WEEC, she has been able to build more rooms for rental. These rooms do not have electricity and this reduces the amount of money that is charged.

column4: The loan applied for will be used for improving the business premises to increase appeal and attract more customers.
column18:
This business is a member of the Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Salome W. is a client who has several years of experience as a business woman. She is married and has been in business for 2 years.

Salome had been operating several other businesses before and she just recently opened a pub at Kiserian town which is doing well. With business experience that she has gained from running other businesses, she has been able to keep books of accounts of her new business. Salome has also employed one female who helps her in running the business whose clients are on the increase. She is been receiving loans at group level and this has helped her to put up her business.

column4: Salome intends to get a loan of USD 700 which will be used to renovate her rental houses. This will enable her increase income by increasing rent.
column18:
This business is a member of the Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Salome W. is a business woman, married and living in Ole Roimen. Most of her business skills have been learnt through years of practice by which she has acquired various businesses.

Salome operates her business of rental houses located in Ole Roimen area. She has a number of rental houses which provide income for her family. In addition to rental houses, she operates butchery and a shop in the same place. She sells kerosene, owns a kerosene pump and a grocery store.

column4: With the money that Phyllis has requested, she plans to improve her welding business and the paraffin one.
column18:
This business is a member of Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Phyllis M. is a very hardworking. She is married and has five children. She is the assistant secretary of the group.

Phyllis operates three businesses jointly with the husband that is selling water, paraffin and welding. While the husband is mostly based at the paraffin pump which is far from the home stead, she manages both the welding and water supply which are at their area of residence. Her businesses are performing well as she is the only person doing the welding and sale of water business in the area.

column4: With the USD 300 that she has requested, Jacinta will be in a position to further expand her business.
column18:
This business is a member of Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Jacinta is a married woman. She has no professional business training but she is very hard working in her day to day business life. She lives in Kiserian where she operates her business.

Jointly with her husband, Jacinta a business of sale of fruits at Kiserian opposite Ngong stage. The business is both retail and wholesale fruits that are sold are mostly bananas but other types can also be found there. Jacinta also operates a door to door business of selling used clothes which she buys from Gikomba Market in Nairobi. Her business outlet is Kiserian where most of her clients reside. Her products are mostly ladies wear; dresses, skirts and blouses. Jacinta has previously taken loans from the group are used to expand both of her businesses.

column4: Mary intends to put up a room which she will use as a shop since the one she is operating from is jut a small structure. This will create room for expansion.
column18:
This business is a member of Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Mary comes from Ole Roimen area. She is the chair lady of the group and has shown excellent leadership skills over the duration she has been the leader to the group.

Her business has expanded from operating a community phone to sale of other domestic food stuff. Her customers are those people who reside in the rental houses near by. Her business is doing well and it has enabled her to pay up her previous loans promptly.

column4: She plans to buy a dairy cow to enable her diversify her income.
column18:
This business is a member of the Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Nancy is a member of Queen Esther Women Group and she is married. Nancy has no professional training in business and also farming but uses indigenous farming methods.

Nancy takes farming as her sole business venture. Mostly she cultivates food crops that range from maize, beans and other types of cereal. Her activities have been affected over the last seasons because of the prolonged drought. She has been straggling with irrigation using local means on a small piece of land but it would have been better if she had a water pump. This is costly and thus would like to buy a dairy cow for zero grazing.

column4: She intends to increase the variety and quantity of foodstuffs to match the demand. So a loan of USD 425 will help her meet the desired demand.
column18:
This business is a member of the Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Gladys is married with two children and a business woman in Kiserian town. She is hard working and has raised her living standard through self employment. She operates a famous eating joint in the area second to none.

Before starting her business she was employed at another restaurant in Nairobi. This is where she got the idea of starting up her own. She saved some money then got a loan of USD 140 supported by the husband, which she used as her starting capital. The experience that she had gained also assisted her to run the business. Currently it is the best in the area and the demand is so high.

column4: She is planning to add more three steers such that she maintains a steady supply to her customers.
column18:
This business is a member of the Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Rachel is married with 4 dependants. She did not have formal education but she was able to educate her children by keeping steers. She is a devoted Christian and a member of Anglican Church of Kenya (ACK) and a Mothers Union member. She is a chairlady of several merry go rounds in Olturoto.

She was given a loan of USD 300 by WEEC in 2001and bought two steers. She later bought She paid very well and qualified for another loan. She sold them and made a profit of USD.200.Her 2nd loan of USD.450 was used for the same business. Right now, she has 10 steers which are about to be for sale.

column4: Hellen plans to increase stock and be able to sell to buyers from the nearby town because they normally miss out on market days.
column18:
This business is a member of the Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Hellen is married with 4 children and 6 dependants. She has been a member of Naretoi women Group for five years. She is a devoted Christian and a member of ACK church.

Hellen was given her first loan of USD.300 by WEEEC in 2001. She Started her business of buying and selling of sheep and goats. She paid very well and was later given another loan of USD.450 in 2003. She is able to buy and sell a minimum of 15 goats and sheep once a week. She is doing very well so far and targets to sell at least 25 per week. This will give her enough income to provide for her family without much strain.

column4: Having established the market, they want to ensure that the relationship they have created with their clients is maintained. Thus this loan will enable them to add more steers in their farm.
column18:
This business is a member of the Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Elizabeth is married with 15 dependants. She was educated up to primary school level, she is able to read and write. She is the current group secretary. She is also secretary to merry go rounds in her extended family. She is a member of Motherâ€™s Union where she is the secretary too.

Elizabeth has a small Farm where she rears 16 Steers. Together with her husband, they started the business in 1998. They have been able to bring up and educate their children. In 2001 she was given a loan of USD 300 by WEEC which enabled them to add 3 more steers. They make sure that they have reasonable stock to ensure steady supply to the butchery.

column4: She intends to restock such that she utilizes the rains which have just started after along period of drought. She will be assured of high income after a few months of grazing.
column18:
This business is a member of the Naretoi Women Group group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Rebecca is married with 6 children .She doubles as church secretary and merry go round.

Rebecca received her first loan of USD.300 from WEEC in 2001. She bought her first 2 steers paid well and in 2003 she was given another loan of USD.450 which enabled her to buy 3 more steers. To date Rebecca has a total of 13 steers. This business enables her to educate her children in good schools and provide for the rest of the family.

column4: Pay worker salary and build two new houses.
column18:
Rebecca K. is a hard working mother of eight; four boys and four girls. She has been an acitve member of Life in Africa since March of 2005. She works as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project which now provides her with a steady income. She also runs a stall at a local market in Kampala from which she also receives some money. Together these two jobs allow her to maintain her large family.

Rebecca is very passionate about educating her children. She says, "They should have the education I never had." But school fees for eight children is very challenging. She is looking for ways to add to her income to insure that this challenge can be met.

Rebecca's church owns some land with clay on it that it makes available to church members for making bricks. Rebecca has already seen one of her daughters do quite well in this business. She is thus seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 500,000 ($280) to fund the start-up of her own brick business.

This investment will create 2 jobs for others who will make the bricks, and she plans on using this business to finance the building of some tenant houses on her property. These she will rent out to further add to her income so that the necessary school fees for her children will be paid.

Below is her budget.

Firewood -- 25,000/=
Transport -- 10,000/=
Labour -- 435,000/=
Total -- 500,000/=

According to Rebecca's current income, she hopes to be able to repay this loan in 10 months. She has designated the impact portion of the interest she pays to support Life in Africa's Integrated Education Program for Adults, where she is currently learning English.

Rebecca's online journal can be found here.

column4: Muthoni plans to use the loan to add more rooms to utilize the plot of land available and increase her income.
column18:
This business is a member of the Queen Esther Women`s Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Muthoni is married, lives in Ole Roimen and the secretary to the group. She was retrenched from one of the insurance companies in Nairobi some time back. There after, she decided to start her own businesses.

She used her small savings to start up a shop at Ole Roimen. With support from the husband and a loan from WEEC, she built one rental room and the rest is history. As the demand for rental houses increased, she sought support from WEEC again. Due to good loan repayments of the previous loans, she was given another loan of USD 600 which she used to construct additional rental houses.

column4: House Repairing
column18:
This business is situated in Sambour Village, Dangkar Commune, Dangkar District, just outside of Phnom Penh

Hak S. is living and working with her husband and 4 children in the suburbs of Phnom Penh city. Her business is to cook and sell food to the workers around the the nearby factories. Each member of the family is involved in this activity: Hak S. gets up at 1am and goes to the fish and seafood market, and then comes back home and start cooking rice, shrimp, fish, soups, dry and fried vegetables. Her husband brings their children to the factories on their motorbike for 9am, which is the morning break for sewing factory worker and they start selling. At home, Hak S. is still cooking to provide fresh food to the worker for their afternoon break at 3:30pm.

This loan of $700 will allow S. and her family to improve their living condition by repairing their house. They will buy materials and perform the reparation by themselves, in addition to their casual workload. Sometimes does Hak S. feel very tired, I want to start another business, she said, but she does not know what she should do.

This is the first time Hak S. takes a loan with CREDIT but her neighbors are old clients and introduce her to CREDIT staff.

column4: Buying a motorbike cart
column18:
This business is located in Thnot Chum Village, Boengtumpun Commune, Min Chey District just outside of Phnom Penh City.
