Kem P. is living with her husband, four children and mother-in-law in a small, two storeys wooden house. Their main activity consists in growing and harvesting water spinach in the nearby fields. The household production is brought to the market in a motorbike cart they have to rent every day, and sold in the market for human and animal consumption.

With the $700 she will receive from CREDIT, Kem P. want to buy the motorbike cart for $120 to save the money of the daily rent. She is also planning to increase her crops through renting one more hectare of land, which is worth $200 yearly. P. will have to purchase more seeds, for $1.25 per 10 square meters, and she knows she will have to work harder with her husband but they expect to increase their annual income over the next few years.

P. is not satisfied with this business: they can barely earn their living with it, she said. Her plan is to spare enough money to open a stand in the market, and sell her neighbors production. In that case, her husband could become a moto-taxi.

column4: Buying a wood carving machine
column18:
This business is located in Poum Kmey, Dangkar District, Dangkar Commune, outside of Phnom Penh City

Keo S. is married and has 5 children. She lives with her husband in Phnom Penh nearby suburbs and they run their business together at home, with the help of one of their sons and one additional employee. The four of them manage to produce two big music instruments every month, out of the yellow wood provided by the partner who markets their production. Each piece is bought for $60 by the shopkeeper, so that this activity generates a monthly income of $120.

With a loan of $1500, Keo S. will acquire a wood carving machine, worth $250, and a motor, worth about $100, to increase the volume and the quality of her production. She will also purchase her own stock of yellow wood, $50 per piece, and other materials required in her activity. This will allow her to substantially increase the income of her family, as these music instruments are usually sold $200 in Phnom Penh markets. We want to expand this business, S. said, because we love doing it. S. has chosen a 12 months loan term and CREDIT loan officer will visit her monthly for repayment collection.

column4: Buying material and motorbike spare parts.
column18:
Thnot Chum Village, Boengtumpun Commune, Min Chey District outside of Phnom Penh City

Khen Samuon is married and lives with her husband and 4 children, 3 boys and 1 daughter, in a small wooden house in Phnom Penh suburbs. She has been working in sewing factories for 7 years, while her husband is self-employed as a moto taxi. Ken Samuon is not very confident about her future but her desire is to support her son to succeed in life.

With the $1000 she requested from CREDIT, Samuon wants to allow her elder son to open a motorbike workshop in Phnom Penh City. She is borrowing for buying the tools, materials and spare parts required for such a business. The family as already found a place for rent for about $60 monthly and the owner has accepted to let them use the premises for free for a one month test period. Khen Samuon and her husband are willing to pay the first monthly installments with their own salaries but they are eventually expecting a daily income of 20,000 Riels, about $5, from the workshop, which will be enough to cover the interest and the reimbursement of the loan and generate a substantial income.

column4: House enlargement and furniture workshop opening
column18:
This business is located in Au Bekam, Dangkar District, outside of Phnom Penh City

Part Sithaot is a nurse; she acts as a medical assistant for the families in the neighborhood. Most of the time, she is living alone with her four children as her husband is a soldier. She moved from Battambang to Phnom Penh 6 years ago to follow her elder son who was starting with the University.

With the $1600 she requested from CREDIT, Part Sithaot will be able to enlarge her house. She has already bought the material but needs this money to hire people to perform the operations. Sithaot will not have any problem to find her labor force among the unemployed youth of her community. It will cost her around $1.25 per day per worker.

With this loan, Sithaot is also planning to open a furniture workshop. She will rent a place, purchase tools and raw materials and employ permanently at least two skilled workers.

Part Sithaot is confident about repaying her loan. It is the second time I borrow from CREDIT, she said, and so far, I have never been late.

column4: She would like to buy another dairy cow and increase stock of her retail shop.
column18:
Florence is married with four children. She has been in the group for 4 years. Currently she is the group treasurer. She is a treasurer of Revelations women group and another self help group. They buy household utensils for members and distribute amongst themselves.\r\n

\r\nFlorence keeps dairy cows and sells milk at Landless and Thika town. She has also a retail shop in Gatundu-Makongeni area. Due to high demand of milk, she would like to increase supply by buying more milk from vendors as well as buying another dairy cow.

column4: Purchase of building supplies
column18:
Milly N. has been an active member of LiA since october 2004, Milly joined with her skills as an artisan making mats and table mats from used straws which have been sold in the LiA gallery, bazaars and hawking them around by her children.

Milly was doing all this to increase on her family income but still there is alot she and her husband can't accomplish with the meagre incomes they get . Their family has expanded; when Milly joined LiA she had four children but now she has given birth to two more.

With her own income now that she is working at the new WE Center across the road from her home, Milly is finding herself newly empowered as a mother and a wife. She has decided that the house they live in is simply too small for 6 children. Her plan is to help the husband to enlarge their house so that they can have enough room to accommodate their big family they have now. She wants to add a bedroom and a living room to their one room they have been staying in.

To achieve this she needs a loan of Ushs. 800,000 and her budget is as follows:

  • Bricks 4000 @ Ushs.60 = 240,000
  • Iron Sheets 24pcs @Ushs. 11,000 = 264,000
  • Bags of Cement 10Pkts @Ushs.18500 = 185,000
  • Timber @Ushs. 60,000
  • Transport @Ushs. 40,000
  • Water @ Ushs.11,000

Total Ushs. 800,000

Milly's husband is a builder and he is ready to do the expansion of the house.

Milly has a surplus of Ushs.260,000 on her monthly expenses to enable her repay her loan in a period of 6 months at a rate of Ushs.147,335. She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she pays on this loan to support new lighting for the WE Center Member Gallery.

column4: Purchase of foodstuffs and household commodities
column18:
Edith N. is a lively and active member of Life in Africa. She is currently working in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project. She is educated and holds a Bachelor's Degree in Development studies but, since finishing her University studies, she has been unable to find a job. She supported herself by doing odd jobs and managed to earn enough money to open a small retail shop.

This shop is in a very good location and is lucrative because there are few other shops in the village. The people would have to walk very long distances to find the products she plans on offering. By bringing these products closer to them she will be guaranteed a large and solid customer base. This will not only provide more income for her but will also serve her community. For this reason she wishes to grow and expand her shop.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to purchase the stock needed to expand her existing shop.

Below is her budget:

  • Sugar 2 bags @70,000/=
  • Rice 1 bag @70,000/=
  • Batteries 2 boxes @ 5,500/=
  • Cooking oil 1 jerry can @ 20,000/=
  • fridge 1 Unit @ 300,000/=
  • Soap 2 boxes @ 10,000/=
  • Maize flour 1 bag @ 12,000/=
  • Salt 2 cartons @ 10,000/=
  • Paraffin 1 jerry can @ 26,000/=
  • Match boxes 1 carton @ 7,500/=
  • Baking Powder 1 box @ 48,000/=
  • Geisha 1 box @ 8,000/=
  • Millet flour 1 Bag @10,000/=
  • contingencies 32,000/=

Total------------------ 800,000/=

She will be paying 102,890/= per month for 10 months in order to completely service the loan properly. Edith has designated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support the Internet4Change team at Life in Africa, where she is an Agent in training.

column4: Purchase & transport of maize flour from the village to Kampala.
column18:
Okidi B. is an active member of Life in Africa working as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. He lives with his wife and three children in the IDP camp known as the Acholi quarter.

He, like thousands of other Acholis, was forced to flee their homes due to the war in the north. Initially at the camp, he earned what little he could at the stone quarry but he found this inadequate since he could not provide enough food, medicine or schooling for his children. Working at LiA has greatly improved his life and now he is able to provide these basics for his family. But he is a business man at heart. He owned a shop in the north and was forced to leave it but his mind still thinks in terms of business.

He has been able to negotiate a busness deal with a local secondary school to provide them with flour each term (three times per year). He will travel to the rural area to buy the flour and then return with it to the school. He will be able to make a profit of 200,000 each term. He will continue with his work at LiA since this business will only require his attention 3 times per year.

He is seeking a loan in the amount of 700,000 to make the initial puchase of flour. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is his budget:

15 bags of maize flour @ 30000/ = 450000/=

Transport 200000/=

Misllenoius 50000/=

Total 700000/=

The nature of his busines gives him time to proceed with his job because he has go and buy once then supplies to school direct. This means he can do it himself just those 3 times and no need for rent. According to his current income, he will be able to pay the loan in 12 installments, and will almost double the loan amount during that period. Okidi has designated the community impact portion of the interest he pays to support the Life in Africa Talent Discovery team.

column4: She would like to buy more chicken to meet the demand of eggs in Thika.
column18:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lydia is married and has four children. She is the Chairlady of welfare in the same group. She is also a of mothers union member where she is a church treasurer. She has been in the group for the last four years.

Currently she has two dairy cows. Has been keeping around 500 chicken a business she started in 2004 using the first loan of USD.300 from WEEC. She sells eggs to local market and Nairobi. The demand is high and would like to increase the number of chicken to at least 1000.She is able to provide for her family all the basic necessities.

column4: Purchase building materials and pay for labor.
column18:
Kilama G. has been an active member of Life in Africa for the last six months. He works as a bracelet maker for the Invisible Children Bracelet Project.

He lives with his wife and children in the Acholi quarters. He has been there for five years ,and he came from Pader district he has six children. Before coming to LiA, he worked in the stone quarry with his wife and had a very difficult time supporting his family. His wife still works at the quarry while he works at liA. Together, their incomes now support the family and their lives have improved. However, housing is very poor in the Acholi quarter.

He has acquired a plot of land from the King of Buganda who has sympathy for the people of Acholi. On this land he plans to build a two room house for his family. For this he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 10 months, and he will be paying 94,000/= per month.

  • 3000 BRICKS @ 60----------180,000/
  • 2 TRIPS OF SAND @ 30000------60,000/
  • 12 BAGS OF CEMENT @ 18000------216,000/
  • TIMBER (4X2) 8 PIECES @3000------24,000/
  • (3x4) 5 '' @500--------25,000/
  • 14 IRON SHEETS @ 10,000 --------------140,000/
  • TRANSPORT----------------------------------33,000/
  • LABOUR------------------------------------------110,000/
  • NAILS 4 INCHES 3KGS @ 1,500/-------6,000/
  • NAILS 6 INCHES1KGS @ 2,000/------2,000/
  • ROOFING NAILS 2KGS @ 2,300/-----3,400/
TOTAL-------------------------------------------800,000/

Kilama will be paying 94,000/= per month in a period of ten months and he saves Ushs 101500/ on his account. He has dedicated 25% of the interest he will pay on this loan to supporting the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu.

column4: materials to produce 100 wallhangings
column18:
Joyce M. is a Patchwork and Embroidery designer specializing in wall hangings of flowers, animals, birds, and persons. She joined Life in Africa 2 years ago and she has since then been a very active member of the WE Center. She has passed on her skills to some of the members of the Center and she is actually the best person one would ever want to work with.

She has developed a good reputation with many International families living in Kampala and they have become customers. She has a stall near her home where she hangs and displays her work but she also does many hangings by special order for her customers. She is now in a good position to expand her business since the demand for her products is now more than what she can produce herself.. And in doing this she will be able to offer jobs to one or two other LiA members to assist her in the production process.

To fund this expansion Joyce is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us. This will purchase enough materials to complete 100 wall hangings. These will be sold from her stall, at bazaars and at exhibitions as well as to her current client base. With the addition of some hired help, she will be able to complete the 100 hangings in four months.

Below is her budget of what she needs to buy.

  • Item/ Quantity/ Cost/ Total
  • Poly Viscose. White 30 Metres x 4000 = 120000
  • Poly Viscose. Cream 30 Metres x 4000 =120000
  • Poly Viscose. Army Color 30 Metres x 4000 =120000
  • Cotton White 90 Metres x 1500 =135000
  • Cotton Cream 90 Metres x 1500 =135000
  • Cotton Brown 90 Metres x 1500 =135000
  • Cotton Green 10 Metres x 150 =15000
  • Transport 20000

Total 800000

According to Joyce's current income, she will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change Team, who need more computers so they can better help Joyce to sell some of her patchworks online.

Read more about Joyce at http://joyceM..blogspot.com/

column4: Purchase building materials.
column18:
Robert O., was born in northern town of Kitgum in 1979 and has lived there until the war was unbearable when he moved to Kampala in 2002.His father was among those killed by the rebels, when he was just ten years old and watching this happened it was impossible for him to continue living in that situation thus the decision to look for safer place, this then was then when he came to Kampala.

While in Kampala Robert now as an adult married with 1 child started learning building skills this was through giving a hand to the mason. This could not earn him enough money so, he decided to join the rest at the stone quarry, a job he did until the news of the bracket project by life in Africa knocked on his door.

This gave him a lot of uplift in his earning that during the few months of working with them, he managed to acquire a small plot that he now wished to develop into a family house.

He therefore seeks a loan of 500,000/= which he will pay back in 12 mouths at 50,415 @

Budget

  • Bricks 1500 x 60/= - 90,000/=
  • Cement 5bags x 18,000/= - 90,000/=
  • Iron sheets 15 x 10,000/= = 150,000/=
  • Roofing poles 10 x 3000/= - 30,000/=
  • Sand 1 trip x 6,000/= - 60,000/=
  • Doors and window frames – 40,000/=
  • Transport – 30,000/=
  • Contingency – 10,000/=

Total ----------- 500,000/=


Since he already has building skills, Robert will be doing his work himself so no labour cost. After this Robert plans to get a bigger land where he will build rental houses that will enable his children go to school. Robert has designated the community impact portion of the interest he will pay on this loan to support educational opportunities for LiA member children.

column4: Capital investment.
column18:
Florence A. is 32 years old and has two children, a boy and a girl. They came to Kampala when the war intensified in Northern Uganda and every body was being forced to move into the IDP Camps. She knew how hard life would be in the camps and she thought she could make a better life in the capital city of Kampala. She is a hard worker and believes in doing whatever it takes to provide for her children. She works at many things including housekeeping and running small businesses. She has had her best success in selling charcoal.

She now works in Invisible Children Bracelet Project at Life in Africa. Her sister, who also was forced to flee because of the war, lives with her and runs the charcoal business. Their lives have much improved but she realizes that the charcoal business can be much more profitable if you have the capital to stock more. For this reason, she wishes to expand her business by seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000.

With the additonal profits from the business, her salary at LiA,and the money she has already saved she plans to buy a piece of land. Here she will build a house for her family to live in and another house to rent out which will increase their income and allow them to live a better and more secure life.

Below is her budget in full:

Charcoal – 40 bags x 8,000/= -----320,000/=

Transport ----------- 160,000/=

Loading -------------- 20,000/=

Total ------------- 500,000/=

She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she will pay on the loan to support Life in Africa's Adult Education Program, where she is excited to now be learning English.

column4: Purchase 2 bales of second hand clothing and pay rent.
column18:
Stephen A. is an active member of Life in Africa. He is a resident of Acholi quarters (a displaced people's camp in the surburb of Kampala). At the camp, his only source of income was the stone quarry where he worked very hard to make barely enough money to exist on. Since coming to Life in Africa, his life has totally changed.

He moved to Kampala as a result of the war in Northern Uganda. There he also was forced to live in an IDP camp and conditions were very hard. He had to leave school when he couldn't raise money for his school fees and his family had a hard time even getting enough food. He now lives with his brother and part of the money he earns he sends to his family back in Gulu to pay for school fees for his younger brothers and to help the family buy food.

His plan now is to start up a used clothing business. His brother has agreed to run the business while Stephen continues his work at Life in Africa. He plans to use the additional income from this business to start saving for building a family house that will enable him to bring down his family who are still suffering in the camps in northen Uganda.

For this business, he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000.

Below are his full budget:

1- 2 bales of clothes @ 150,000/= ------ 300,000/=

2- Transport ---------- 40,000/=

3- Rent for space @ 30,000/=@month ----- 90,000/=

4- licence --------- 50,000/=

5- contingencies ---------- 20,000/=

TOTAL ------------ 500,000/=
With the income he now earns through the WE Center Kampala, Stephen will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. He has designated 25% of the interest he pays to support the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu.

column4: Purchase building materials and pay labor.
column18:
Abdon O. has been an active member of Life in Africa for six months. He currently works at the WE Center as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project.

He is Acholi and his home used to be Gulu in Northern Uganda. However, in 1997 the war there became so dangerous that he was forced to flee and come to Kampala where he lives in the displaced persons camp known as the Acholi quarters. There, he and his wife worked in the quarry and barely earned enough to feed their five children much less provide such things as school fees. He now works at LiA while his wife continues at the quarry. Their combined income can now provide a much better life for the family.

But living conditions are not good in the camp and he dreams of having a home of their own. He has acquired a piece of land donated by the King of Buganda and it is his intent to build a modest two room home on it so that his children will not have to live in a rented house. To do this he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us.

Below is his break down.

He wants to buy the following materials

1: 12 iron sheets @----------------11000--------132,000/

2: 12 bags of cement @--------------18500-----201,000/

3: 3000 bricks @ 60-----------------------------180,000/

4:13 pieces of timber for roofing

(3x4)- 3000----24,000/

(4x2)-----5000-------------------20,000/

5: 2 trips of sand @----------60000----------------120,000/

6: transporting materials to the site-------------- 40,000/

7: Labour-------------------------------------------83,000/

TOTAL: 800,000/

According to his current income, he will be able to repay this loan in 12months and he will be paying 80,665 per month. O. has designated the community impact portion of the interest he will pay to support the Transport for Life in Africa team, which is currently trying to raise money for a LiA community owned vehicle that can help transport workers to the WE Center.

column4: Purchase building materials.
column18:
Edidah is a wonderful woman and is a very active member of Life in Africa. She is the sole breadwinner for seven children. She is very talented in the art of handicrafts and earns her living by making and selling beautiful basket, bracelets, shopping bags and many other items.

She faces several challenges in her work. The first is that she is an asthmatic. This makes it very difficult to work during the cold and wet season. However, she does not let this fact stop her and she works hard even when she is sick. These skills, her determination and her good business sense allow her to provide the basic needs for her family. Her other challenge is providing the school fees to educate all her children. Their education has become her number one priority.

To overcome this last challenge, Edidah has devised a plan to constuct a two room house that she will rent out. She owns a plot of land located at Mutungo near Kampala and she has family there to help in the constuction of this house. This project will take about three months to complete and once it is finished, she will use the income from this property to pay the school fees that will insure the education of her children.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 500,000.

Below is her budget:

  • Cement - 12 bags 200,000/=
  • Doors - 2 pcs 90,000/=
  • Wood - 20 pcs 100,000/=
  • Labour - 85,000/=
  • Bricks ((3500in number) 24,500/=

Total 500,000/=

Loan Amount 500,000/=

Edidah will be able to repay her loan in 10 installments. She has designated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support the WE Team for developing self-sustaining project at LiA, which she currently leads.

column4: A loan of USD.750 will help her to buy a new computer to easy her work and good storage students’ data.
column18:
Agnes is married with four children. She has trained on secretarial, computers and an accountant by professional. She is a CCI member.

She started her private computer college eight years ago. She is the Managing Director of the college which has 170 students. Thika is a densely populated town and most school leavers have missed vacancy in her college due to lack of enough computers and training materials. The college has employed 8 members of staff.

column4: Her wish is to buy a refrigerator so as to provide cold drinks and stock the different items which are frequently asked and are not there at present.
column18:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Eunice Muthoni is the current chairlady of Revelation women group. She has been the Women Coordinator of St Stephen Anglican Church of Kenya for the last five years. She is married with 5 children.

She started her small shop in 2003 after being given her first loan of USD.300 from WEEC.Landless area is a dry area and sodas and other cold drinks sale easily. The population of the area is growing very fast and at times runs out of stock of some items which is not good if you are to attain and retain customers.

column4: The loan applied for will be used to repair the lorry.
column18:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Edith is married with 4 children. She is hardworking and a good member of PCEA church.


Edith has a banana plantation in Maragua District in central Kenya. She also grows and sells maize and beans. Edith has been in this business for the last two years. She also has a lorry for transport business. It is normally hired to carry building materials in Thika. Thika is an industrial town where construction works is at an increase. This business has built her a house and is about to be completed.

column4: Grace wants to start up community phone services and a retail store near her church to bring services nearer to the people.
column18:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Grace is a pastor of Regeneration church in Thika, Kenya. Through her church ministry, she has traveled to Uganda, Tanzania, Sudan and Rwanda. She has been a member of Revelation women group for the last 4 years. She is a mother of four.

In 2005 she received a loan of USD.300 and bought a cow. To date she has two dairy cows. She also practices horticulture farming on a small scale. She sells milk, onions, and cabbages to her neighbors and in Thika town.

column4: Given a loan of USD.300, Jane will be able to upgrade her salon and increase stock of her shop.
column18:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Jane is married with six children. She joined the group in 2003. She is an active member of the group and the local self help group.

Jane started her business of selling cereals in 2003. She was given her first loan of USD.300 by WEEC and had trained in hair dressing. Therefore, she started her own salon in Thika town. The business has grown and handles mores than 10 people a day.

column4: She plans to increase stock of rice as well as buy materials for ladies wear because they have ready market. Therefore, a loan of USD 300 will contribute to realizing her dream.
column18:
"This business is a member of the Revelations Women group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Fredah is married with one child. She is an active member of Revelation Women Group .She is enterprising and multi skilled, she makes shoes, belts, dresses, trousers and shirts.

Fredah got her first loan from WEEC in 2004 of USD 150.
She started selling rice after resigning her job in a leather factory. Her wish was to own a business however small it was in order to be independent.
She sells over 200kgs per month earning her USD 71 as profit.
In addition, her tailoring business brings in extra income. She is to open up a bigger stall in thika town for easy merchandising.

column4: Jane intends to invest the USD 300 into her business and use it to buy paint. There ready market hence she will be able to pay her loan with ease.

They own a small plot in Kware and want to construct rental rooms. A loan of USD 300 will assist them to start up the project. At least they want to start with three rooms and rent them at USD 10 each per month.
Margaret wants to rent a semi permanent stall to enable her display her finished work and tap more customers.
The loan that has been requested will assist Jennifer to buy malaria drugs because it affects a number of people in the area. She also wants to develop her plot at Gathiga.
Given a loan of USD 300 Miriam will enable her to have a permanent stall and also add stock of new baby clothes.
column18:
"This business is a member of the Kandisi Wisdom Women group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Miriam is married with two children who are in lower primary. She had to start a small business to assist the husband cater for the household expenses as well as household development.

In year 2005, Miriam received USD 27 from her husband that enabled her to start a small business of used baby clothes. She used to select assortment of baby jumpers, truck suits, socks that could move fast. This enabled her sales turnover to be high. She ploughed back the profits and this enabled her stock to grow. At the end of 2005, Miriam joined WEEC program. She got USD.55 and added more baby clothes plus baby shoes. Miriam has also received trainings especially on business skills and management; she is able to keep her business records. Miriam saved USD 3 per month and has saved a total of USD 38. So far, her profit per day is about USD 7 per day.

column4: The USD 600 loan will be used to include other soft drinks in her retail shop to meet her customers’ needs.
With a loan of USD 550, Mary plans to buy more pigs.
Given a loan of USD 450, Mary will add her stock to enable her give her customers better services.
The loan of USD 600 will be used to increase her stock and use the rest of money will be put in milk business.
A loan of USD300 will help her maintain the chicks and allow a normal growth of this business.
column18:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Peris is 40 years old, married with 6 dependants. She is the chairperson of Future fruit.

Peris started dairy farming way back in 1992. From the sale of milk, she was able to construct rental houses.
She distributes her milk to hotels both in Nairobi and Kiserian. She also rears chicks for sale. There is potential market for chicks and milk. Withdraws from the business to pay school fees retards business growth.

column4: With the USD 225 she will increase stock and this will attract more customers.
column18:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Bethua is 40 years old, married and has five dependents. She is educated up to secondary level and she lives in Ole Roimen, Kiserian Town. She is the secretary of this group.

Bethua started her business in 1996 as a sole proprietor. She borrowed before from the groups’ revolving fund and used the money to expand her business. She operates her small shop at the same place she resides. With proper training on business and credit management, from WEEC, she has been able to run her small business well.

column4: If a loan of USD 150 is given, she will increase her stock so as to attract more customers to her stall.
column18:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Lydia is a 32 year old and is married with four children. She is the treasurer of this group.

She has been operating this business for the last two year. The business is growing steadily and sales are improving day by day. She has been getting small loans from the groups’ revolving fund to finance her business. But, she now feels that she needs a bigger loan since her business is growing rapidly.

column4: Sale of Produce and Milk
column18:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Beatrice is 42 years old. She is single, has 6 dependants and lives in Matasia.

Beatrice sells maize and beans. She also has a dairy cow and sells milk. Due to the prolonged drought that has hit the country; she plans to concentrate on Zero grazing of Dairy cows because she is assured of income daily.

column4: A loan of USD225 will be used to expand her rearing area and to add on the number of chicken.
column18:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruit Women group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Jane is single and lives in Kiserian. She is 42 years old, a secondary school graduate.

She has been in this business of rearing chicken for the last 6 years. The business has been doing well and she sells chicks, layers and broilers in Kiserian town. She is now an established supplier of broilers in the area.

column4: Improve Inventory
column18: Maria G. is originally from Azuay but has lived in Guayaquil, Ecuador for more than 30 years. She has owned this store for 23 years with the help of her husband and only son. Her husband is in charge of buying merchandise for the store, but he can only buy as much as the store sells in the short term. Therefore, the store has very little in stock and cannot buy at larger quantities with cheaper prices. She has made efforts to seek loans from banks but has been rejected and she cannot pay the 20% monthly interest rates that local informal lenders offer. With the $500 loan she will be able to take advantage of better deals from her wholesale providers and also diversify her products.

column4: Purchase Materials
column18: Cesar Hugo is a 58 year old blacksmith who specializes in the production of metal doors, window frames and fences. These products are in high in demand in poor sectors in order to protect businesses and homes from robbery. Cesar has 4 sons who work with him on his business which is operated out of his mother’s home. Currently he can only work when he receives an order because he does not have the money to buy materials so that he can make products in advance. He hopes that this loan will allow him to make some doors and gates he can display in order to attract more clients and sell at faster rates.

column4: Improve Inventory
column18: Angel Conforme is 52 years old and has 3 children. He’s owned this store for about four years and counts on the help of his wife who also works part time for a bakery and of his kids when they are not in school. He sells all kinds food items but concentrates on selling candies, snacks and other foods for people on the go. He is in need of capital so that he may improve his current product offerings and sell at lower prices. It is very difficult for him to maintain his inventory without the power to buy in bulk.

column4: Purchase Materials (Fabrics)
column18: Sotero P. is 45 years old, was born in the province of Manabi in Ecuador, is married and has a 6 year old son. Sotero is a tailor who makes suits and uniforms of all types. He operates his business out of his home for over 32 years and has the help of his wife and a partner who purchases some of the suits he makes in order to resell them. He is in dire need for capital in order to increase production for the upcoming school year. He expects that demand will be high because students will need new uniforms and teachers will also be looking for new work attire. In order to meet the demand he must buy more materials to make the clothing. He is hopeful that he will receive the loan in time to make these products.

column4: Stationary Services
column18:
Mariam is married with three children. She has been in business over the past ten years. She runs a stationery and schools supplies shop in Dar es Salaam. Her shops stocks general stationery (files, ball pens, maker pens, counter books, flip charts, office pins , paper clips, paper punches etc). Recently she introduced primary and secondary schools textbooks. The new line of business requires high capital because the number of schools has increased in Dar es Salaam due to the high priority now given on education by the government. The new line requires high lumpsum of money to meet seasonal demand for textbooks especially in June and December/January before new semesters starts.\r\n

\r\nGiven a loan of $1000, she plans to increase his stock by buying more stationery and textbooks. The loan term will be twelve months. She has a well established credit history with Microfinance Institutions.

column4: Purchase of decoration lamps, artificial flowers, table cloth
column18:
Mossy Doss runs two business, decorations at functions/ceremonies (weddings, business meetings etc) and a boutique. She was educated up to secondary education. She could not get a job because employment opportunities are limited especially for girls. Her parents decided to send her for a tailoring course, where she completed and started her own tailoring mart. Later she discovered that during weekend there is high demand for decorations business. She decided to learn the skill through apprenticeship. The new line of business keeps her busy particularly on Fridays and Saturdays when weeding and other cerebrations takes place. \r\n

\r\nThe loan of US$ 1000 will assist her purchase up to date decorations materials and equipment. The materials are locally available through importers who normally get them from Far East. She an experienced borrower and she is confident that she will repay her loan on time. Her business makes her move from one venue to the other every time. She works hard to meet clients orders and meet their expectations.

column4: Gloria plans to use her $400 loan to expand her local restaurant and satisfy her regular customers by accomodating them better. She intends to buy more tables, utensils, as well as cooking items like oil, sugar, and rice...
column18: Gloria M. was born in Guayaquil, Ecuador. This 40-year-old single mother of three opened her restaurant 10 years ago. Her clients are all regulars from her neighborhood, and they all enjoy the tasty food she offers day-in and day-out. Gloria works from 6am serving breakfast to the morning crowd until 4 pm when she serves lunch. This $400 loan will allow her to accomodate her devoted clients better and expand her business.

column4: Luis plans to diversify his fruit inventory with this loan capital, and he also will be able buy more items in bulk. Because he will have enough cash to purchase more fruit, he does not have to buy his fruit on credit (which can be very costly)
column18: Frutas Don Luis, which has been open for 29 years now, would like to thank Mifex and Kiva for advertising the need for business capital. He moved to Guayaquil, Ecuador from Cotopaxi (sierra region) 40 years ago to start a new life for himself and his family. At the age of 53, Luis has plenty of experience selling his fruit, but he needs vital capital to expand. He runs his shop along with his wife, so they can continue to provide a better life for their children. His three children are grown up now and live independent from the family, and he would like to improve their lot. Until now, Luis has been unable to gain access to credit from any institution.

column4: Monica and her husband, who helps the run the bakery, would like to use the $600 to be able to buy ingredients including flour, sugar, butter, and oil. Both she and her hasband run the business, while one of them typically handles the finances. They would like lenders to know they are excited.
column18: Mónica S., 39 years old, was born in the province of Manabi. She is married with 2 children that are in school. The bakery which is located downstairs from her house is in a part of town where there is not an overabundance of bakeries. Also, the business lies along a main thoroughfare, so plenty of traffic passes by their store. From 6am until 10pm Monica and her husband sell bread and other bakery items. They know how to run their business efficiently, but they lack the capital to expand.

column4: Finish walls and roofing
column18:
C. Bosco has been an active member of Life in Africa since 2005. He currently works at the WE Center as a gatekeeper and he also makes bracelets for the Invisible Children Bracelet Project.

Like so many others who have been forced to leave the war torn Northern Uganda, he and his family live in the displaced persons camp known as the Acholi quarters. He supports three children and working in the stone quarry made it impossible for him to earn enough money. Since coming to Life in Africa, he now earns enough money to make their lives much easier since they now have money for food, rent, and more important, for the school fees for his children. Now he feels proud and for the first time, he can start to see a future for his family again.

His first priority is to build a family home. He wants his children to have the security of having their own home again. He has a plot of land that the King of Buganda donated to the Acholi some years ago. He has already started to build his home but was forced to stop due to lack of funds. He is now seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to finish this home. He will be able to repay this loan in 6 months.

LOAN AMOUNT: 800,000

PLAN: BUILDING

He wants to buy the following materials

1: 12 iron sheets @----------------11000--------132,000/

2: 12 bags of cement @--------------18500-----201,000/

3: 3000 bricks @ 60-----------------------------180,000/

4:13 pieces of timber for roofing

(3x4)- 3000----24,000/

(4x2)-----5000-------------------25,000/

5: 2 trips of sand @----------60000----------------120,000/

6: transporting materials to the site-------------- 40,000/

7: Labour-------------------------------------------78,000/

TOTAL: 800,000/

C. plans to pay back this loan in 6 Months in amounts of 147,335 per month and he saves Ushs 170, 500/= per month. He has designated the community impact portion of the interest he will pay to support Life in Africa's Talend Discovery team.

column4: Buy tools and materials
column18: Manuel A. is a blacksmith who has a relatively young business. He learned his skills from his job with another metal worker but had decided to venture on his own and begin offering these products in his own neighborhood because the demand is high. Currently he operates from the backyard of his home working on projects from the clients in his area. He must ask them to provide 50% of the costs upfront because he cannot afford the materials otherwise. Obviously this slows down his business and he could use the loan to buy tools and supplies that will allow him to make doors, gates and window frames in advance to increase sales.

column4: Buy in bulk to improve inventory
column18: Jose R. is a 52 year old store owner who has had his shop for about 14 years. He is not married but has the responsibility of taking care of his 11 year old adopted son and his mother. His store is on the bottom floor of his home and is located well in order to attract clients from the area. With the loan Jose will buy more merchandise to sell at lower prices. Jose is completed dedicated to his business which is open from 6am to 11pm. His hard work and perseverance have allowed him to buy his home and fulfill the responsibilities of being a father.

column4: Buy flour, butter, baking soda etc.
column18: Vicente R. is a 50 year old father of two boys. For over 11 years he and his wife have owned a bakery that is very popular in his neighborhood. They begin baking at 6 am every morning and continue to sell throughout the day and night until about 10 pm. They will use the loan to buy ingredients for their bread like flour, butter and baking soda and will also consider purchasing complimentary goods that they can sell with their current product. This business has provided a living for them and their children and allowed them to build their current home.

column4: Purchase of bottled soft drinks, various refreshments, chicken, juice, milk, hygienic paper, basic sugar, grains.
column18:
My name is Simona M.. I am owner of a small local grocery store for seven years. This is located in front of the soccer fields in this community, which strategic for my sales. With the gains that I obtain from my business , it helps to pay for schooling for my three children. My children also help with the running the business in their free time after school and on weekends. 

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Simona M., soy dueña de una pulpería desde hace siete años, esta ubicado frente a las canchas de foot ball en esta comunidad, lo que estratégico para mis ventas, ya que a partir del jueves mis ventas aumentan.. Con las ganancias que obtengo de mi negocio ayudo a mis tres hijos en sus estudios, ellos también colaboran en el negocio en sus ratos libres y fines de semana.

column4: Buying Botelled refreshments, sausages, chicken, juices, milk, \t\t\t\ttoilet paper, sugar, basic grains.
column18:
I am Blanca P., I have a local grocery store in which I sell soups, bread, sugar, drinks, chicken, and other products for daily need. I have the store for fourteen years, my clients ask me to sell meat; which would be profitable because in this area there are no butcher shops and my clients have to go all the way to the market. With my earnings I help care for my four children, who also help in the store.

Descripción del Negocio: Yo soy Blanca P., tengo una pulpería en la que vendo sopas caseras, pan, azúcar, refrescos, pollos y otros productos de consumo diario. Lo tengo desde hace 14 años, mis clientes me piden que venda carne; que seria rentable ya que en esta zona no hay carnicerías y tienen que ir hasta el mercado. Con las ganancias que obtengo ayudo a sostener a mis cuatro hijos los cuales también colaboran en el negocio.

column4: Lubricants, tires, products to repair tires.
column18:
My name is Eduardo B., I have a shop located next to the highway that goes to the city, for five years I have provided services such as tire repair, I also buy second-hand tires and sell them as spare tires. With my earnings, I support my family of three children, all of whom are in school.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Eduardo B., tengo un taller ubicado a la orilla de la carretera hacia la ciudad, desde hace cinco años doy el servicio de reparación de llantas, también compro de segunda para venderlas como llanta de repuestos. Con las ganancias que obtengo sostengo a mi familia de tres hijos los cuales están en la escuela.

column4: Buying children’s underwear, men’s, women’s and children’s summer shirts, socks of various sizes and bathing suits.
column18:
My name is Agueda M. and I have been selling  underwear and sportswear for nine years, my clients prefer me because of the attention I give them and my good prices. This business permits me to help support my family and finance the higher education of my three children.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Agueda Mejía me dedico a la venta de ropa  interior y deportiva desde hace nueve años, mis clientes me prefieren por la atención que les doy y por los precios. Este negocio me permite ayudar al sostenimiento de mi familia y a financiar los estudios superiores de mis tres hijos.

column4: Buying children’s clothes, trousers for women, men and children, underwear.
column18:
I am Santos S., I have been selling clothes for six years. My store is located in the market in my city, which is heavily visited by people traveling through town, the majority of my sales are to people who sell my items in other cities. With my earnings I support my wife and my two school aged children.

Descripción del Negocio: Soy Santos S., me dedico a la venta de ropa desde hace seis años. Mi negocio está ubicado en el mercado de mi ciudad por lo que es bastante visitado por personas en transito, vendo al por mayor a personas que se dedican a vender en otras ciudades. Con las ganancias que percibo mantengo a mi esposa y dos hijos en edad escolar.

column4: Buying underwear, trousers for men, women and children, beach towels and bathing suits.
column18:
My name is Victor S., I have been working in my clothing store for eight years. It is located in the market of my city and is frequently visited by neighbors and people traveling through town. At this moment in time I would like to have more summer clothes. My family consists of my two children and my wife and we have to work to support our small family.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Víctor S., me dedico a la venta de ropa desde hace ocho años. Esta ubicado en el mercado de mi ciudad por lo que es bastante visitado por vecinos y personas en transito. En este momento quiero tener mas ropa de verano. Mi familia es de dos hijos y mi esposa por lo que tenemos que trabajar para mantener a mi pequeña familia.

column4: Buying new shoes for men, women, and children as well as clothing for children and women.
column18:
My name is Ramona A. and I have been working in my shoe store for eight years, I need a loan to supply my store because we are beginning the school year, but also for sandals for the summer and for the large amount of tourists. With my earnings I receive I help to support my family of three children.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Ramona A. me dedico a la venta de calzado desde hace ocho años, necesito el préstamo para surtir mi negocio ya que todavía estamos iniciando la época escolar y para sandalias para época de verano ya que hay bastante visita de turistas. Con las ganancias que obtengo ayudo al sostenimiento de mi familia de tres hijos.

column4: Buying trousers for men, women and children, summer clothes and underwear.
column18:
My name is Enoe L. and I have been working in my clothing store for twelve years, even now I continue to have many clients because they like my manner of attending to them and my prices. In the summer months I have a large demand for shorts, short sleeve shirts, towels with scenes of our city, because we receive many tourists here. I have three school ages children who help me in their spare time.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Enoe L., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva hace doce años, hasta ahora tengo mucha clientela ya que les gusta mi manera de atenderlos y los precios. En esta época de verano tengo bastante demanda en la ropa como short, camisetas, toallas con paisajes de nuestra ciudad ya que nos visitan bastantes turistas. Tengo tres hijos en edad escolar quienes me ayudan en sus ratos libres.

column4: Buying new shoes, book bags, and briefcases.
column18:
My name is César C., I am twenty years old and I have been working in this shoe and book bag store for five years. I inherited this job when my father passed away and I continued the business, attending to customers, trying to give them good products and affordable prices. Right now, I am finishing high school, which I have to quit for a short time when my father died, because I had to take care of my mother and three younger siblings, who also go to school and help in other way to help support our family.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es César C.,  tengo veinte años de edad, me dedico a la venta de zapatos y mochilas desde hace cinco años. Recibí este puesto cuando falleció mi padre y continué con el negocio atendiendo a la clientela, trato de darles un buen producto y precios accesibles. Actualmente estoy terminando mis estudios secundarios los cuales abandoné por poco tiempo cuando murió mi padre, ya que me hice cargo de mi madre y tres hermanos menores, los cuales también estudian y ayudan en otras actividades para sostener a la familia.

column4: Buying bottled refreshments, sausages, chicken, ham, milk, toilet paper, sugar, basic grains, milk products.
column18:
My name is Ramón H., I have a job selling products of daily consumption in the municipal market of the city. I have had this this job for two years, I depend on my loyal customers and I go out of my way to help them and give them good products and fair prices. I have two children and my wife, to whom my earnings go to, to help with expenses and food.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Ramón H., tengo un puesto de venta de productos de consumo diario en el mercado municipal de mi ciudad, Tengo dos años de tenerlo activo por lo que cuento con mis clientes fijos ya que me preocupo por atenderles y darles buenos precios y productos. Tengo dos hijas y mi esposa por lo que los ingresos que percibimos me ayuda con los gastos y alimentación.

column4: Buying book bags, briefcases, belts.
column18:
My name is Antonio M., I have been selling rush-hats, leather belts, backpacks and briefcases for five years, I get my products from local artisans in my city. They are products that are produced primarily in this part of Honduras and are distributed on the national level, our city is one of the most visited by tourists and has tourists  year round. With my earnings from my business I support my three children who are in college.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Antonio Mejía, me dedico a la venta de sombreros de junco, fajas de cuero, mochilas y maletines hace cinco años, mis compras las realizo a artesanos de mi ciudad ya que son productos que se producen mayormente en este departamento de Honduras y son distribuidos a nivel nacional, nuestra ciudad es una de las mas visitada por turistas y el movimiento es de todo el año. Con las ganancias de mi negocio mantengo a mis tres hijos que estudian en el colegio.

column4: Buying underwear for men, women and children, book bags and briefcases.
column18:
My name is Cleotilde B.. My store is in the municipal market, I sell clothes, book bags, pañaleros ( a type of clothing), baby clothes and other things, for five years, with my earnings I get from my business, I pay for my personal expenses, now that I am advanced in age, it is the only income I have.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Cleotilde B., tengo mi negocio de venta de variedades en el mercado municipal vendo ropa, mochilas, pañaleras, ropa de bebé y otros hace cinco años, con los ingresos que percibo de mi negocio pago mis gastos personales ya que soy una persona de edad avanzada y es el único ingreso que tengo.

column4: Buying tennis shoes, summer sandals, short sleeve shirts, shorts, and belts.
column18:
I have been working selling shoes, clothes and belts in my community market for three years. I started this business when I retired and I found it difficult to find a job because of my age. With my earnings I receive I maintain my wife and three children who study at the university.

Descripción del Negocio: Me dedico a la venta de zapatos, ropa y fajas en el Mercado de mi comunidad hace tres años. Este negocio lo inicie una vez que me jubilaron y me ha sido difícil encontrar trabajo en alguna institución por mi edad. Con las ganancias que obtengo mantengo a mis esposa y mis tres hijos que estudian en la universidad.

column4: Buying plastic silverware, flowerpot holders, glasses, cups,  plastic cooking items, wastepaper baskets.
column18:
My name is Marcelino B., in my business I sell plastics, market baskets, cups, disposable silverware, bags for wrapping, tablecloths, napkins and other items for four years. My biggest clients are restaurants and canteens. With my earnings, I finance my personal expenses and those of my wife as we no longer have our children in our home.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Marcelino B., mi negocio es la venta de plásticos, canastas de mercardo, vasos, platos, cubiertos desechables, bolsas para envolturas, manteles, servilletas y otros desde hace cuatro años. Mis mayores compradores son los restaurantes y comedores. Con las ganancias que obtengo solvento mis gastos personales y de mis esposa ya que no tenemos a cargo hijos.

column4: Buying knittings, underwear for men, women and children, trousers for men, women and children and beach towels.
column18:
My name is B. S., I have been working in my clothing shop for nine years, my store is at the entrance to the municipal market of my city. My husband and I run the store, but since we are both older in age, our children help us, our earnings are enough to cover out expenses.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es B. S., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva desde hace cinco años, tengo mi puesto de venta en la entrada al mercado municipal de mi ciudad. Este negocio lo administro junto a mi esposo ya que ambos somos mayores y nuestros hijos ya no nos ayudan, las ganancias que nos genera son las suficientes para cubrir nuestros gastos.

column4: Pedro is posting on Kiva because he needs capital to buy more bike parts, improve the appearance of his shop, and attend to his clients better.
column18:
Reason for Borrowing- Pedro M., who was born in Guayaquil, is a 49-year-old bicycle salesman who has been in business for 3 years. His small enterprise is located in the house that he and his brothers inherited from his father. His bike shop is strategically located because there is not another similar business like this nearby. Working from 9 am until 7 pm, Pedro desperately needs this capital to serve his clients better. He would like lenders to know that he is running a professional bike shop and that he is very responsible.

 

Justificacion de Credito- Pedro M. nació en Guayaquil, tiene 49 años de edad, es soltero, posee un negocio de venta de repuestos y arreglos de bicicletas desde hace 3 años, el negocio esta ubicado en su domicilio que fue herencia de sus padres con otros hermanos, la ubicación es estratégica porque no hay ese tipo de negocio en la zona y esta muy bien ubicado, atiende de 9:00AM hasta las 7:00PM., el esta solicitando el crédito para comprar más repuestos y surtir su negocio y atender mejor a sus clientes. Se pudo observar que Don Pedro es una persona que conoce del negocio y muy responsable.

column4: Restocking shop for ladies' garments
column18:
Joy K. is a lady who believes in hard work, she joined Life in Africa in August 2005 and ever since she has worked hard to make ends meet in her life. She has since scheduled herself to both her jobs, selling her shop of ladies fashions and also working for the bracelet project for the Invisible Bracelet Campaign at Life in Africa.

She wants a loan to restock her shop with new fashions so that she can be able to capture more customers. She needs a loan of Ushs. 800,000 and her budget is indicated below.

  • 1 bale of ladies' Cotton skirts @ 200,000
  • 1 bale of ladies' silk blouses @ 170,000
  • 1 Bale of ladies' cotton dresses @ 180,000
  • 1 bale of ladies'double breast coats@ 220,000
  • Transportation @ 30,000

She wants to repay this loan in 12 months at a rate of Ushs.80,000 and her expenses verses income is Ushs.225,000. She saves Ushs.80,000 per month on her account.

She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change Team, who need more computers. Read more about Joy at http://lifeinafrica.com/4/joyK.

column4: Buying washing machine
column18:
Ismael has a small room at his home in Bukoto which is suitable for a Laundry. He has done this business before. He has tried it out with rudimentary methods, which has limited him to certain customers. The clients with heavy woolen clothings like blankets, coats, bedcovers,etc which require the use of a washing machine. What he needs now is to improve on the standard of his work and also be able to cater for all these customers. He needs to buy the necessary equipments and this is the reason why he is requesting for a loan. The number of people who require his services have also increased. This is because his only competitors got their houses demolished after their landlord selling off the land where they were operating.

Ismeal lives in Bukoto, this is the next place to Ntinda where Life in Africa is situated. He has a wife and two children living with him. He joined life in Africa in october 2005, as a trainee internet4change Uganda. He got ajob with invisible children as a bracelet maker in Febuary 2006. Before he was doing this work but since he got another job as mentioned above, his cousin will help him do the laundry work. He has already saved 100,000/= for detergents and some few things he may need to add. He will also pay his cousin 30,000/= per month for helping him. He is requesting a loan of 700,000/= payable in 12 months. He will be paying 70,000/= per month.

Below is his budget:

  • Washing Machine 500,000/=
  • Counter Board 80,000/=
  • Ironing Board 30,000/=
  • Flat iron 30,000/=
  • Polythen Covers/coat covers (12) 6,000/=
  • Metallic Hangers (12) 5,000/=
  • Installation of machine and Labour 50,000/=
  • Total 701,000/=

Ismael's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by his community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. He has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest he pays on this loan to support LiA's Internet4Change Team. For more about Ismael, his life and his world view, visit him online at http://lifeinafrica.com/4/lubingaismael

column4: Family house
column18:
A. Grace is an active member of Life in Africa working as a bracelet maker in the invisible children bracelet project. She lives with her husband and child in the IDP camp know as the Acholi quarters. Her husband works as a carpenter.

They, like so many other families, had to flee their home in Gulu because of the war. They find life in the camp difficult. They are able to earn enough for the basic needs but they know that they would be much better off if they could eliminate the rent which is one of the biggest expenses.

They have acquired a plot of land from the king of Buganda who donated free land to the Acholi. Here A. and her husband plan to build a two roomed house and, once it is done, this will free up a good part of their income to be used for other purposes such as food and helping their relatives. The husband is a carpenter and is able to mobilize his colleagues to help in the construction thereby saving the labor costs.

For this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 700,000/= that she will repay in 12 months at a rate of 58,333/= per month.

Below is her break down:

-99 poles both for the wall and the roof @ 2000 each = 198,000/=

-18 iron sheets ‘gauge 23’ @ 10,000/ = 180,000/=

-4 bags of cement @ 72,000/=

-water to be used in the construction =30,000/=

-transport =30,000/=

-sand 1 trip= 50,000/=

-2 wooden doors @ 50,000 =100000/=

-2 woodenwindows @ 20,000/= 40,000/=

Total=700,000/=

Grace's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Adult Education program. For more about Grace, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/graceA.

column4: Buying Materials to complete house
column18:
Fred T. is an active member of Life in Africa. He has proved himself to be a very hard worker as a sander and bracelet maker for the Invisible Children Bracelet project.

Fred is a father of four children. It is very expensive raising children and providing them with school fees, food, medical care and housing. He manages but knows that there are ways he could improve their standard of living.

When his father died, Fred inherited three, two room houses in Makindye which is a suburb of Kampala. His family currently lives in one of the houses and he rents out the other two. But the houses are only partly finished and so he can only charge a small rent. If the houses were properly finished, he could rent them for more money and this extra money would enable his family to live an easier life. It would also provide better housing for his tenants.

For the reasons above, he requests a loan in the amount of 700,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. He will be paying 70,000/= per month.

He will use the loan as below:

Cement 10 bags each bag at 19,000/=............................190,000/=

Sand 2 trips each at80,000/=...................................160,000/=

Doors 3 each at 60,000/=...................................... 180,000/=

Windows 3 each at 40,000/=.....................................120,000/=

Labour..........................................................50,000/=

Total..........................................................700,000/=

Fred's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by his community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. He has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest he will pay on this loan to support the Community Guaranteed Lending Team at Life in Africa. For more about Fred, his life and his worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/fredT.

column4: Retail shop and tailoring
column18:
Monica is an active member of Life in Africa. She joined in November of 2005 and currently works as a wire sorter for the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She is one of the younger members being only 20 years old. She is an orphan. Her parents died when she was only 8 leaving her and her two brothers alone.

They were taken in by an aunt but life was very hard. The aunt, who was a widow herself, was taking care of many children and the grandmother who is blind. With very little money, food was often scarce and the only schooling Monica could afford was a tailor course. She did manage to get a job but could not earn enough money to exist on. Then she came to LiA. She now earns enough to help with food, rent, school fees for her brothers and support for her grandmother.

With encouragement from her determined aunt, she is learning to be independent and to forget that she is an orphan. She has managed to save enough to set up a small shop. Her cousin runs the shop during the day while Monica works. Now she would like to do more. If she adds more stock to the shop, her profits will increase. She also plans to use her tailoring skills by purchasing a sewing machine. Since her shop has a big veranda, she will put this sewing machine there and use on the weekends to earn money. For this project she is seeking a loan of 800,000/=. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months at a rate of 66,667/= per month.

Below is her budget:

  1. A sewing machine @ …………. 250, 000/=
  2. adding stock:
  • 100kgs of rice @ 900/= ………………90,000/=
  • 50kgs of sugar ……………………70,000/=
  • 20 liters of cooking oil…………….40, 000/=
  • 100kgs of maize flour @ 600/=……60,000/=
  • 60kgs of beans @ 1,000/=………….60,000/=
  • 50kgs of groundnuts @ 2,000/=…….100,000/=
  • 50kgs of Simsim @ 1,500/= …………75,000/=
  • 1 box of washing soap ………………...25,000/=
  • Transport ………………………………30,000/=

The total is 800,000/=

Monica's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change team. For more about Monica, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/atimmonica

column4: Buying and grinding the maize
column18:
Grace is an active member of Life in Africa. She joined through the Acholi Quarter Satelite Center. She moved to Kampala from the Gulu in the North to escape the war but she does not live in the quarters. However, she went there each day to work in the rock quarry. This was very hard on her since she had no money for transport and this forced her to walk 3 kms each way. She earned barely enough money to survive on but she had no choice since the survival of her family depended on what she could earn. Many days they had no food and they lived under the constant threat from the landlord of being thrown out of their home.

Grace's move to Kampala also has another reason. While still in the North, Grace and her husband had divorced and she was left with her eight children to fend for themselves.

Life in Africa has given Grace and her family new hope. The association with others and the sharing of knowledge and skills has given Grace the idea and desire to start a business. School fees for eight children is almost impossible and she worries, especially about the older girls. Her plan is to open a maize flour shop near her home. She has a 25 year old daughter who will work the shop. I talked to the daughter is she is very excited. It will not only give her work to do but she is happy that she will be earning money to help her mother and perhaps help pay school fees for her siblings. For this project Grace is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is her budget in full:

1- Maize 10 bags @ 50,000/= --------------------- 500,000/=

2- Grinding 10 bags @ 6,000/= --------- 60,000/=

3 - Rent for 3 months @ 50,000/= --------- 150,000/=

4- Transport --------------------------------------- 90,000/=

TOTAL -------------------------------- 800,000/=

Grace plans that with all she will save, she can send all her children back to school.

Grace's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Educational opportunities for LiA member children. For more about Grace, her life and her worldview visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/gracefA.

column4: community water installation
column18:
L. Irene is an active member of Life in Africa working in the invisible Bracelet project as a bracelet maker. Before coming to LIA, she earned her living working in the stone quarry near the Acholi quarters.

She was forced to flee Northern Uganda because of the war and, as most displaced Acholi, she settled in the displaced persons camp. Life there is very hard and basic needs are hard to come by. One such need is water. There are few tap water supplies and this makes it very expensive for the people to get water and they have to walk very far.

Her plan is to install a water tap in the part of the quarter where she lives. She will be able to provide the water at a less expensive rate and it will also benefit the community by shortening the distance they have to travel to get water. There has recently been another installation of a successful water tap but the quarters are very large and one tap will not fill the needs of so many people. This will give her a strong customer base and make it a profitable business venture. For this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/=. She will be able to repay the loan in 12 months at a rate of 66,667/= per month. Once cash is at hand, the whole processes to have tap water is only one to two weeks.

Below is her break down:

35 pieces of metallic pipes @ 10,000 =350,000/=

Labor charges ……………………… 300,000/=

Construction of shelter against wastages….100,000/=

Charges from national water authority ……30,000/=

Transport……………………………………10,000/=

Other ……………………………………….10,000/=

The total amount is 800,000/=

Irene's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's talent discovery team. For more about Irene, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/labongirene

column4: Building Family House
column18:
L. Mary is an active member of Life in Africa. She works as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project. Here she earns enough to support herself and her children.

She is Acholi and was born in Northern Uganda. Eight years ago she was forced to flee the brutal war in the north and since then she has been living in the camp known as the Acholi quarters in Kampala. Here she lives in a small rented house. However, she has acquired a plot of land which was donated by the King of Buganda because of his sympathies for the Acholi. She now wishes to apply for a loan in order to build a two roomed house for her family. Growing up during 20 years of war and living eight years in a camp have made having a permanent safe home a priority. For this she is asking for 600,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Poles for the wall 120 @ 2000/ = 240000shs

Iron sheets 12 @ 10000 = 120000shs

Roofing timbers 15 @ 5000 = 75000shs

Nails 10kgs @ 2000 = 20000shs

Labor = 120000shs

Total = 575000shs

Mary's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery team. For more about Mary, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/lalammary

column4: Building Family House
column18:
K. Adrine is an active member of life in Africa. She is a single mother of two children. She was deserted by her husband and left to make a life the best she could. Being poor and a single mother is very difficult but she works hard in spite of the challenges to provide for her children and give them the education she never had.

She works for Invisible Children Crew as a bracelet maker. This helps her provide for the basics at home and even pay school fees for her children. Her son will be joining Kyambogo University this coming year. The greatest challenge she has, is having no house in the village. She had to leave her children in the village with her family while she came to Kampala to earn money. When she goes to the village to visit them, she has to share a room with her brothers. It is not easy to get one family to share their home with another family when they are already crowded. In Kampala she is only able to rent one small room for herself and she dreams of the day when she will be reunited with her children.

Her plan is to build a house in the village where her children will live comfortably and where she will stay on her visits. Her son and her brother will supervise the construction for her. She owns two cows which she plans to sell. They are worth 900,000/=. In addition to this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/= to complete the project. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. Her payment will be 50,000/= per month.

Below is her budget:

Bricks 3000 @ shs. 60...........................................180,000/=

Cement 15 bags @ shs. 18,000................................... 270,000/=

Sand 2 trips @ shs. 60,000..................................... 120,000/=

Timber, nails and iron sheets.................................. 303,000/=

Shutters....................................................... 200,000/=

Transport....................................................... 70,000/=

Labour..........................................................200,000/=

Total.........................................................1,343,000/=

Adrine's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's craft product development team. For more about Adrine, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/adrinekyalisima

column4: Building Family House
column18:
kwero Evalyn has been an active member of Life in Africa since 2005. She is employed as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She has three children and she lives in the Acholi quarter which is a camp for displaced persons from the north.

She and her family were forced to flee their home in the north because of the war. They settled in the camp as did most Acholis who fled to Kampala and she earned what little money she could by selling bananas. She would tie her baby on her back, carry a basket of bananas on her head, and she would walk all day trying to sell enough to make ends meet. She barely earned enough to pay the rent and feed them so school was just not possible. Since coming to LiA, their lives have greatly improved.
