Grace has been a farmer all her life and therefore has experience in dairy and tea farming. A large acreage of her farm is under tea but has set aside an area where she grows fodder for her cows which are zero grazed. Grace bought her cows from tea proceeds as well as the loans she got from Our Lady of Unity women group. To date, she has successfully repaid 9 loans from her group. Her previous loan was of USD 500. She gets USD 30 per month from sale of milk and USD 220 from tea. With the loan applied for, she intends to buy a water pump so as to be able to get water from a nearby river for her cows. This has been a problem due to the steep terrain of her farm. This will enable her better manage dairy cows and get more milk for sale. She also intends to buy farm inputs-fertilizers and cattle feed.

column4: Grace wants to improve her poultry farming that is Buying feeds and expanding the shed to get more space.
column18:
Grace is married with 3 children and is 43 years. Her husband is employed and is currently educating 2 children in University. Due to her strong community mobilization and leadership skills, she holds many leadership positions in church and in the community. She is currently the area zonal chair lady responsible for supervising 8 groups. She has been in her group for 6 years.

Grace has one dairy cow, 600 chicken (layers) and a quarter acre of land under horticulture and 2 acres under tea. She gets USD 120 from milk, USD 1000 from sale of eggs, USD 150 from tea and USD 120 from horticulture sales .She started chicken farming early last year from a loan of USD 750 she got from her group has been able to meet her client’s orders. With the loan applied for she intends to improve on the housing of the chicken to ensure that they are sheltered from bad weather conditions and also that there is more space for additional chicken in future. Part of the loan will also be used to buy chicken feed in bulk.

column4: Lucy deals stocksn a variety of household products. The loan will be used for buying more stock such as maize flour, beans, sugar, salt, soap,generally to increase her stock level.
column18:
Lucy is 36 years old and married with 3 children. 2 of her children are in primary school in a nearby private academy. She is also the group secretary.

Lucy started her business 3 years ago as a kiosk in Kabati town, which is quite vibrant due to being near a highway. This has however grown to the current general shop selling a variety of commodities. She was able to do this from the loans that she accessed from her group. She has received 4 loans from her group and successfully repaid them back. Her previous loan was of USD 120 was used to buy cereals for her shop to meet the huge demand that was there due to a prevailing drought in the country. She makes a profit of USD 75 per month and intends to add more stock in her business by buying a variety of goods in bulk from wholesalers so as to get a wider profit margin.

column4: Margaret is in the process of improving her farm and thus the loan will be used for buying improved seeds and fertilizers.
column18:
Margaret is married with 5 children and is 48years old. One of her children is waiting to join college and is currently assisting her at the farm together with her husband.

Margaret previously was used to subsistence farming-maize and beans. But she realized that this would not sustain her family and meet her family growing needs. That is when she rented a small farm and started growing French beans and cabbages. This has seen a huge transformation in her life as she is now able to make a monthly profit of USD 300 from her farming. This has enabled her send her children to school and live a decent life. The loan applied for, she intends to expand her farming by purchasing farm inputs-seeds and fertilizers so as to grow more of the cabbages and French beans. She gets orders from as far as Thika town and the buyers usually come to buy from her at the farm and therefore does not incur transport costs.

column4: Pamela wants to buy more chicken such that she \r\nincreases the supply of eggs currently in short supply in Thika Town.
column18:
Pamela is married and has 5 children. She is a high school teacher and an active member of the Anglican Church and an official of the church council. She is the treasurer of Plains view self help group. Her 5 children are all in school and her husband is employed.

To supplement her employment income, Pamela started poultry and dairy farming in her rural home in Gatundu. She has 350 chicken (layers) and 2 dairy cows. She has employed one person at the farm but always ensures she is there when she is free and over the weekends. She sells 11 crates of eggs per day at USD 25 and 25 litres of milk at USD 5 per day. Her total income from farming every month is USD 900. Gatundu is a fast growing area and Pamela would want to increase the number of her chicken to be able to serve this readily available market better. She already has orders that she is not able to meet.

column4: Susans success in farming has pushed her to starting a small retail business near her home. This will assist her in sselling her milk and farm output.
column18:
She is 50 years old, married, has 5 children, 2 of whom have completed secondary school and 1 has completed college and is looking for employment.. She is also the group secretary.

\r\nSusan has a dairy cow; also she is a horticultural farmer, banana farmer and grows maize and beans. From her farming she is able to generate USD 150 per month and also feed her family. She bought her dairy cow from a loan of USD 120 she got from her group and income from her farming. She intends to start a small business in Githunguri shopping centre which is quite vibrant to supplement her income from farming. She will be assisted by her son who has received some formal business training but is currently unemployed. She previously had a shop in Muhutini but closed it due to insecurity. She thus has the necessary experience to manage the business.

column4: Compra de Mantequilla, Queso, Quesillo, Frijoles, Maiz, y leña.
column18:
I have been working for three years selling dairy products such as small cheeses, butter, cheese, also corn, beans and firewood. In my community I am one of the only people who sell these products, which are basics for daily consumption. I hope I can increase my earnings and help my children in their education at the university level.

Loan Use: Buying butter, cheese, small hard cheeses, beans, corn and firewood.

Tengo tres años de dedicarme a la venta de lacteos como quesillo, mantequilla, queso, maiz, frijoles y leña. En mi comunidad soy una de las pocas personas que venden estos productos y que son basicos para el consumo diario. Espero poder incrementar mis ingresos y poder apoyar a mis hijos en sus estudios universitarios.

column4: Compra de frijoles, maiz y Leña.
column18:
My name is Maria Socorro and I sell corn, beans and firewood. I have been working for four years in this business, which I began with my own money. In the rainy season, people look for me so they can buy firewood, because in this area, we do not have electricity. I know that with the help (loan), I will be able to better my family’s earnings.

Loan Use: Buying beans, corn and firewood.

Mi nombre es Maria Socorro y me dedico ala venta de maiz, frijoles y leña. Tengo 4 años de dedicarme a esta actividad, la que inicie con mi propio capital de trabajo. En los meses de lluvia las personas me buscan para comprar leña, ya que esta zona no tenemos luz electrica. Se que con el apoyo que me brinden podre mejorar mi ingreso familiar.

column4: Compra de Ropa para niño, dama, cosmeticos, ropa de cama, cortina, sandalias, ropa interior.
column18:
I have a small business, which is located in my house. I have been selling clothes, cosmetics, and shoes, for 15 years. My job is hard because I have to leave to go to offices to sell my products, but it is worth it, because my earnings enable me to help my children in their studies,which is especially important because one is already studying at the university.

Loan Use: Buying clothes for children and women, cosmetics, bedclothes(pajamas), curtains, sandals, and underwear.

Tengo un pequeño negocio ubicado en mi casa, vendo ropa, cosmeticos, y zapatos desde hace 15 años. El trabajo es duro porque tengo que salir a oficinas a vender mis productos, pero vale la pena ya que mis ingresos me dan la oportunidad de ayudar a mis hijos en sus estudios, logrando que 1 ya este en la universidad.

column4: Compra de leche, pan, huevos, harina de maiz, refrescos, cafe, azucar y otros
column18:
I have had a small grocery store called Oneyda, in my home for three years, I attend to the store alongside my wife. Our clients are satisfied with the attention with which we help them, and also for our quality products at low prices. Our earnings help us to pay our familial and financial obligations.

Loan Use: Buying milk, bread, eggs, cornflour, sodas, coffee, sugar and other items

Tengo una pequeña pulperia llamada Oneyda en mi casa de habitacion desde hace tres años, esta la atiendo junto a mi esposa. Nuestra clientela se siente satisfecha por la atencion que les brindamos, ademas por los productos de calidad y bajos precios. Los ingresos que percibimos por las ventas nos ayudan a cubrir nuestros compromisos familiares y financieros.

column4: Compra de Carne de res, cerdo y pollo.
column18:
I have been working for three years in my butcher shop, selling pork, beef and chicken. My shop is located in the transportation terminal of my town. My products are good and all the people that travel here from other towns buy my meat to take home with them. Now the demand is greater because our town is growing in size. Thanks to my earnings, I can help my family with the expenses of education and food.

Loan Use: Buying pork, beef and chicken meats.

Tengo 3 años de vender carne de cerdo, res y pollo en mi carniceria zelaya, esta ubicada en la terminal de transporte de esta ciudad. Mis ventas son buenas ya que todas las personas que viajan de otras ciudades compran carne para llevar a sus hogares. Ahora la demanda que tengo es mayor ya que nuestra ciudad ha crecido en poblacion. Gracias a los ingresos que obtengo ayudo a mi familia con los gastos de estudios y alimentacion.

column4: Compra de azucar, cafe, huevos, jabon, refrescos, pan y otros.
column18:
My name is Adelina and I have owned my shop for 5 years. It is located in one of the terminals in town, where I sell all types of ítems for basic daily consumption, along with my husband, we attend to our clients reliably and formally. Our earnings that we generate from our business help us with our familial and financial obligations.

Loan Use: Buying sugar, coffee, eggs, soap, sodas, bread and other items

Me llamo Adelina, tengo mi pulperia Kelin desde hace 5 años. Esta ubicada en una de las terminales de esta ciudad, aca vendo toda clase de producto de consumo basico familiar, junto a mi esposo atendemos a nuestra clientela que es bastante cumplidora y formal. Los ingresos que nos genera el negocio son para ayudarnos con nuestros gastos familiares y financieros.

column4: Compra de baterias, jugos, leche, churros, galletas, condimentos, cafe y otros.
column18:
My name is Asunción and my business is called M.’ Grocery Store. It is located near to the school Jose Trinidad Reyes, which helps me sell my products. During the night I sell sweets because there is a lot of traffic in this area and the school has three daily segments of classes. My earnings help me care for my children in their studies and in my familial expenses.

Loan Use: Buying batteries, juices, milk, churros ( a type of sweet pastry), cookies, condiments, coffee and other items.

Me llamo Asuncion, y mi negocio lleva el nombre de Pulperia M.. Esta ubicada cerca de la escuela Jose Trinidad Reyes, lo que me ayuda a vender mis productos. Por las noches vendo golosinas ya que esta zona es bastante transitada y el colegio tiene tres jornadas diarias de clases. Los ingresos me ayudan atender a mis hijos en sus estudios y gastos de familia.

column4: Compra de rollos fotograficos, camaras, papel para fotos y otros.
column18:
I work taking photos of events and of people, also for passports and kin. I have 5 years experience and in my community, I am contracted to cover events such as reunions, parties or press events. My business is family owned and operated, but I have two young assistants who help me take photos and develop them. I like to take photos and thanks to this job, I am able to work to support my family.

Loan Use: Buying rolls of film, cameras, photographic paper and other items.

Me dedico a tomar fotografias de eventos y personas, tambien para pasaportes y carne. Tengo mas de 5 años de experiencia y en mi comunidad me contratan para cubrir eventos en reuniones, fiestas o ruedas de prensa. Mi negocio es familiar pero tengo 2 jovenes que me ayudan a tomar fotografias y revelarlas. Me gusta tomar fotos y gracias a este trabajo he podido apoyar a mi familia.

column4: purchase materials to improve his fanily's house
column18:
T. Sarin came to CREDIT office with his wife to request a second loan, after successfully repaying the first. After investing his first $500 to have his house connected to the electricity network, he is now applying for a $1000 loan, whose main purpose is to improve their family house. As a self employed mason, Sarin has a great experience of construction. He will use $700 for buying the materials required and perform the works by himself.

The remaining $300 will be invested in the soy bean milk business Sahin’s wife is running on her side.

Every active member of the family will contribute to the repayment. Sarin usually earns around $7 a day, while his wife can make $2 profit out of $25 soy bean milk sales. Their eldest daughter is 26 and employed in a sewing factory and her $80 monthly salary might also help. Their two youngest sons are still going to school.

“Since we started borrowing from CREDIT, our standard of living improved”, they said. ‘We would like our children to study at the University, if possible abroad”, they added.

column4: Running Capital for a grocery shop
column18:
Kaeiv Navy is married and father of children. He is working at the National Assembly of Cambodia, as a support staff.

He applied for a $500 loan for his wife to open a grocery shop. She used to run a similar business but the family sold it a few years ago, when her eldest son got married. Navy’s wife will use the money as a running capital to purchase spices and other goods to be sold in the shop. They are expecting 10,000 Riel ($2.5) profit from the shop every day, which will cover daily expenses for food.

This is the first time Navy is borrowing money. “If we are successful, we will increase the size of the business step by step with our future loans”, he said.

column4: Running capital for a vegetable shop
column18:
S. Saphean is married and mother of three young children. In addition to her casual domestic tasks, she is alS. earning her living by selling vegetables in the market at night. Her husband is a cook and enrolls for frequent weddings ceremonies. He takes care of the children at night, when Saphean is out to the market.

With the $1100 loan she requested, Saphean is planning to expand her business with a bigger stand and more diversity in her products. She hopes to increase her income from the market and would alS. like to open a small shop in front of her house to sell cane juice during the day.

column4: purchasing a motorbike and a pig
column18:
M. Ban is married and father of 8 children. They are all living at the same place. His wife is growing rice in a field near their house for the family consumption, while their two eldest sons are employed in factories and their eldest daughter is waitress in a restaurant. 

M. Ban is selling watches and glasses on a mobile stand on different places such as markets and bus stations in and around Phnom Penh. For the moment, he is walking from one place to another or sometimes hiring a moto-taxi. He is selling his glasses for around 3000 Riel ($0.75) and his watches for 4000 Riel ($1). On sunny days he can sell for $20 and earn around $5 profit.

M. decided to borrow $500 from CREDIT. He will first purchase a cheap second-hand motorbike for $300, so that he could move to more places and increase its profit. M. wants to raise a pig the family house as well. It will cost $200 but they expect and exceptional income from the sale.

column4: Purchasing a motorbike and mason tools
column18:
S. Dara has been self employed as a mason for more than five years now. He learnt this job from his father and took over the business when he retired. He lives with his wife, who is employed in a factory, and their four children.

For the first time, S. Dara is borrowing $700 from CREDIT because he wants to expand his activities and needs additional tools to perform the works required by a client. He will spend $500 in purchasing a motorbike, that will allow him to go further and faster and find more clients. He will also buy special scissors designed to cut steel for covering the roofs for $50 and another electric machine to cut floor tiles for $80.

His current client will pay him $600 for one and half month labor on building his house. “I am not worried about repaying this loan”, he said, “and if the business keeps going well, I would like to build a bigger house for my family!”

column4: Margaret wants to increase the number of steers for her to supply more in the markets of Kiserian and Isinya.
column18:
Margaret is married with one child. She went up to secondary school. She is the secretary of Umoja women group and actively participates in training members on group issues especially the running of the revolving fund.

\r\nMargaret started her steers business in 2004. She received a loan from the revolving fund that enabled her to buy two steers. She wants to increase the number to at least 15 steers such that she has a constant supply. She sells her steers in Isinya and Kiserian markets. Trainings in modern methods of livestock management have helped her in keeping good breeds avoiding inbreeding thus having quality steers all the time. This has increased demand for her steers, a major drive to keeping more.

column4: Nashipae wants to buy two steers which will be fattened and sold in 4-6 month.
column18:
N. is 23 years old, married have no child but takes care of one girl of a relative and she is in primary school. 

N.`s main activity before joining Umoja women group was bead work and looking after her husband`s cows. When she joined Umoja women group, and was trained on modern livestock management, she decide to start a small steers’ project. She took a loan of USD 118 and bought 2 steers. After 4 months she sold them at Isinya market and got USD 225. This encouraged her and now aims at keeping 8 steers at a go and selling them as they mature to enable her generate income throughout the year. She intends to market at Isinya and Kitengela township. This will assist her take care of her dependant and also her children in future.

column4: This loan will be used to buy three steers to be grazed for 6 months and later be sold
column18: W. is 52 years old a widow and has 6 children. She did her primary education and is the treasurer of Umoja women group. W. has struggled hard and has managed to educate 4 of her children, 2 up to college. She has been rearing the indigenous goats. When she joined Umoja women group she was trained on modern livestock management. Due to the vegetation devastation in Maasailand women received training and prepared them for a positive change. W. is happy that the new changes will enable her educate all her children since the steers will give her more income. From rearing of indigenous goats, W. has now bought 3 steers with a loan of USD 180 that she received from her group and paid it back. Her aim is to reduce the number of goats and engage in selling steers.

column4: To buy more timbers and carpentry tools.
To increase value to the milk.
To expand ox-plough spare parts
To stock more phones and accessories.
To increase the stock.
Increase the stock of used clothes.
To increase the stock of clothes.
Increase the stock
Buying leather materials.
To add more produce in the stock
TO increase the stock of wedding atire and decoration materials.
To increase the stock of produce
She won a tender to supply beef 140 kilograms per week to a neighboring secondary school. The loan will be used to buy more cows.
column18:
She is 54 years old, a widow with 5 children. Of five children, 3 are independent. One is in college still under her support and the other in secondary school. Both assist her in farming during their holidays.

Gladys has been in this business for 11 years. Also she carries out coffee farming and keeps livestock on a small scale. Her business has been performing very well over the years because of less competition within the area and she has regular customers.

column4: She would like to buy an improved breed of dairy cow.
column18:
She is 50 years old widow with 5 children, 2 are in a technical college and the other in High School.

Grace has been in farming for 26 years and this has been the source of income. She has been able to educate her children up to college level. She has 3 hectares of land with coffee trees and 3 Dairy cows which in aggregate brings a net income of USD180 per month. The milk market has improved and there are better terms of payment of dairy products offered by cooperative societies. She wants to replace in phases her dairy cows which on average produce 8 litres of milk per day with a better breed that can produce approximately 18 litres per day. Once this project is fully implemented she will increase her earnings more than double.

column4: She would like to stock cereals because of having higher returns.
column18: Susan is 56 years old married with 5 children, 2 are still depending on her even after finishing school due to unemployment. She has been in this business for 8 years and deals more with fast moving consumer goods e.g. rice, sugar, maize flour and cereals. Cereals have higher returns and their prices are not as volatile as the rest of the products.

column4: She wants to purchase a sowing machine to avoid expenses of going to the tailor.
column18: Phyllis is a young lady aged 23 years, single with no children.She has been in this business for four years and on average making a profit of about USD 75 per month. She washes them, irons such that they look flashier and modifies some to be fashionable. She wants to purchase a sowing machine to avoid expenses of going to the tailor.

column4: She wants to stock the new malaria drug which is abit expensive but very effective.
column18: Winfred is 28 yrs old and single.This is the only business of its kind in Gaitheri trading centre and its services are in demand by the community. This clinic has been in operation for 5 years and members from the community have trust in her and really appreciate her services.

column4: Janet wants to buy a better breed dairy cow to increase milk supply.
column18: Janet is 36 years old, single with 4 children. Her children attend school, 1 in High School and 3 in primary school.Janet sells milk and she has been doing this business for last seven years. She also sells fodder, vegetables such as cabbages and kales to bring in extra income. The prevailing market conditions in terms of demand for milk, good prices has encouraged her to replace her cows by a better breed which will give her 18 litres per day instead of the previous 8 litres.

column4: She would like to improve on her premises to meet the required standard and buy a good quality dairy cow.
column18: Grace is 30 years old, married with 2 children both in primary school.Grace sells milk and calfs a business she has been doing for 5 years with returns of about USD 75 per month. She sells her milk in Kiambugi trading centre and to the neighbors. She is planning to get rid of the existing cows which are of low quality and replace them with high breed whose milk production is far much higher.

column4: She needs money to purchase a higher capacity cooker that would be able to increase the output of chips two folds.
column18: Florence is 24 years old single with no children.She has been in this business for 3 years and employs 2 casual workers. She prepares chips and traditional foods such as Ugali, mixed vegetables-Sukuma week, and porridge. Chips move very fast and she experiences shortage during peak hours at lunch time. Currently the existing cooker can not allow her meet the demand during these hours.

column4: Muthoni wants to diversify her business and include ladies and children’s shoes.
column18: Eunice is 35 yrs old married with 4 children, 2 are in primary school and 2 in boarding secondary school. She has more than 8 years experience in this business which has been generating an average monthly net profit of 100 USD. Her business has been sustainable due to minimum operational costs as she operates in an open air market. The fact that she moves in various markets, enable her to meet more customers.

column4: She would like to purchase 12 aluminium cans and each cost USD 25.
column18: Margaret is 34 yrs old, married with 5 children. Her two children are in High School, 2 in primary school while the other is yet to join college. She has been doing this business for the last two years and has recorded tremendous achievement because she has been able to pay farmers on daily basis unlike cooperatives which pays on monthly basis. She has been using plastic Jericans but this has been stopped recently by the cooperatives that they are not hygienic. This has forced milk vendors to buy aluminium cans.

column4: Caroline would like to stock new clothes to be and 1st class second hand clothes.
column18: Caroline is 27 years old, married with one child. Her husband runs a small butchery in Rongai. She joined WEEC Credit program in 2003. She has attended various business courses organized by WEEC and this has helped her do her job and duties of group secretary. She started a small business of selling second hand blouses in Rongai in 2002. She was given a loan by her group of USD 225 and set up a small semi permanent beauty shop and clothes. The small business is doing well so far and has managed to pay her loan without any problem as well as living decently

column4: Esther wants to stock cereals and buy more local chicken
column18:
Esther is married with one child. She was forced to drop out of school to take care of her youngest sister when her mother passed away. With her sister’s upbringing and education falling on her at such an early age, she sought for an income generating activity. She joined a women’s group and received basic business training courses that WEEC provided for its members.

 In year 2003 Esther received her first loan of USD 60 to start a small business. She started a fruits business. She put her stall near Hardy supermarket so as to target those who want to buy fresh fruit other of the supermarket. The fruit business is doing well and has enabled her to educate her sister up to secondary level. Esther believes that discipline and hard work is the core of any business success. To this, she is the discipline mistress in her group. Esther’s dream is to expand her business to include cereals. She has started a special project of keeping local chicken and they are in high demand compared to broilers. Each local chicken costs USD 4.

column4: Running Capital
column18:
P. Pheap came to CREDIT office in Phnom Penh because she just repaid her first loan and want to start a new cycle. This time, she is requesting $550 to invest in the business she is running with her husband.

P. Pheap and her husband have been selling foxes for food consumption on Psar Kandal, one of Phnom Penh biggest market for more than 4 years already. Fox meat dishes are highly appreciated in Khmer traditional cuisine and are prepared on special events and in a few restaurants. P. Pheap buys the animals from catchers from several provinces of Cambodia, such as Kompong Thom, Pursat and Kompong Chhnang, and sells them alive with a margin of about $1 per kilo.

This activity is not an easy one, but it has been covering the expenses of the family for a while now. P. Pheap is proud to say that 4 of her 5 children are going to school. The youngest is only 4 months old and her wish is to build a bigger house for her growing family.

column4: Buying seeds and renting land for the next crop. Building a bridge between her house and the village main path.
column18:
S. Nan is harvesting water spinach on a small piece of land she rent near to her house, in the outskirts of Phnom Penh City. She lives alone with her grown daughter, who is 23 years old and already employed in a sewing factory. In the morning, she gets up at 5am to harvest the water spinaches. She takes a break between 11am and 2pm, when the sun is too hot and then goes back to the field until 5pm to sow new plants.  

S. Nan requested a $600 loan from CREDIT to pay the rent for the land and to purchase seeds for the next harvest. She also needs wooden sticks and string to delimit her field. This will cost her around $300.

With the remaining $300, S. Nan will have a bridge built between her house and the main path of the village. With the rainy season about to start, this improvement becomes critical for her. Last year, she had to use a boat to reach her house. She hopes the works can be completed before August.

The business is breeding around 30,000 Riels daily and with her daughter salary, S. Nan is really confident about repaying this loan. But she is dreaming about moving to another place because of the floods in the area.

column4: purchase tools and raw materials for her husband's business
column18:
P. Nen is married and lives with her husband and young baby in Phnom Penh suburbs, around 20 kilometers from the center of the city.

She decided to borrow $1,000 from CREDIT to help her husband in his business. He is running a small shop in the city and makes windows and doors out of materials such as steel, iron and glass. As he started only three years ago, his shop is still small but the business is profitable and he wants to expand. With $1000 he will purchase tools and raw materials to increase the quality and the volume of his production.

This business is already breeding $10 per day and P. Nen is also running her small business: she has got a sewing machine at home and makes clothes to be sold in Phnom Penh. She learnt these skills by helping her friends and now she can make around 50,000 Riel ($12.5) per week.

P. Nen wants to continue doing this activity, because she can look after her baby while her husband is busy outside.

column4: Building a new house
column18:
K. Siphan is a grandmother living with her mother, and her Son’s family. They moved from Phnom Penh city to this newly populated area only one week ago but they already started building a proper house to shelter the seven of them from the heavy rains of the coming months.

K. Siphan requested $500 for her first loan with CREDIT because the family need fund to buy the material to complete the works, but also for investing in the small shop she is already operating on her new land.

K. Siphan's son is employed by the Cambodian Red Cross in a nearby Health Center Project and earns a regular salary of $135 per month.

K. Siphan is making around 10,000 Riel ($2.5) daily income from the shop but she expects more profit in the future, when she will expand her business with additional products.

column4: Building a new house
column18:
K. Chandara is requesting a $500 loan because she recently moved from Phnom Penh City and would like to have a house built for her family. The works have already begun but she needs additional funds to purchase materials and hire 2 workers to help her husband. They will come from the countryside and will be paid 10,000 Riel ($2.5) a day, plus accommodation and meals.

K. Chandara also wants to invest some money in purchasing a cart for her husband’s tuk tuk (a personal transportation vehicle pulled by a motorbike). For the moment he is renting it for $60 per month which represents almost one third of the income generated by this activity.

When the house will be built, K. Chandar would like to start a business as well. She is thinking about selling porridge in her village in the morning.

column4: Repair Floor, Buy Tools for cabinet-making
column18: Anita, a 32 year-old originally from Manabi, Ecuador, has three children, two of whom study at the colegio. Unfortunately, her third son who is 14 years of age does attend school because Anita and her husband cannot afford it. Sra. C.’s husband works as a cabinet maker and makes $120 every month. Anita has always had an entrepreneurial spirit, and once she married, she wanted to pursue her dream of opening a breakfast restaurant with her husband.  They began by running the small restaurant out of their home, but they realized 5 years ago that they would need a larger location to accommodate the growing number of customers that frequented their place. This husband-wife team has been able to improve their home which is in an area of Guayaquil called Isla Trinitaria. With the profits from business, Anita and her husband have been able to re-do the structure of their house to brick. She wants to borrow $585 so that she can put in new flooring in her house. The way things are right now, her family is very susceptible to flu and other throat sicknesses because the flooring is just dirt. Also, Anita would like to buy more utensils for her restaurant.

column4: Buy wood for cabinet-making
column18: Edeisi, who was born in Esmeralda, Ecuador, has lived in Guayaquil since she was very young. Now, this 42 year-old mother of two lives with her husband in a marginalized area of the city referred to as Isla Trinitaria. Edeisi and her partner had to wait 10 years to obtain the title to their house as well as many other hardships. They lack potable water which costs $1 per tank, hygienic services, and a mode of transportation. Now 7 years widowed, Edeisi is left with her two children who are almost independent and her husband’s cabinet making business. When he passed away, Sra. B. still had possession of all of the tools, but she took the initiative in finding a worker who could continue the business to continue bringing in money for the family. One of her sons markets the finished products in the local markets. Edeisi is asking for this $365 loan to buy more wood to continue making cabinets as well as a polisher.

column4: Buy more inventory for Mini Market
Buy refigerator to keep catch of the day fresh
column18: Luis is a 40 year-old native of Guayaquil who has two children and a living wife. His wife is a mannequin maker, and “Lucho” used to work in a factory. Left without work, Luis had to learn how to sell fish to continue providing for his family. For 7 years Sr. A. has worked as a fish salesman in a local market. He arrives at 4:00 am every day to buy his fresh products in the grand market, and thanks to the help of his wife, they have been able to make improvements on their home from mud and raw materials to cement. Don Luis needs this loan to be able to buy a refrigerator to keep his fish fresh throughout the day.

column4: Purchase more household items for mini market
column18: Pedro Quiñónez, originally from Columbia, has lived in Guayaquil, Ecuador for 10 years. He is a 56-year-old married man with 3 children. His business sells household provisions and treats. Pedro’s venture is run out of his home and he has been in this business for 5 years. Clients from the neighborhood can buy goods there from 9:00am until 11:00 pm. Sr. Quiñónez woul like to take out a $475 loan to buy more inventory and purchase special order items from his regulars. Don Pedro is a hard-working entrepreneur that wants to grow his small business and advance his family’s situation.

column4: Purchase more diverse supply of fish; Market products better with display case
column18: Yesenia Guadamó, a 29 year-old single mother originally from Vinces, Ecuador, has lived in Guayaquil for 15 years. Since she and her husband split, she has been responsible for their two children ages 6 and 7. A good friend of Yesenia’s encouraged her to open a fish market, and so she started a small business a few years back. Sra. Guadamaó opens shop at 4:00 am and usually sells out by 1:00 pm. With her revenues from one day, Yesenia will buy fish for the next, but she would like to expand her offering by taking out a $365 loan. She wants to buy seafood like fish, shrimp, and shellfish like crab and scallops. This microloan will allow Yesenia to buy in cash, whereas now she currently purchases goods on credit for a one-day period and pays nearly double to settle the debt. She wants to strengthen her business and build a board with which she can display her fish. One of the side benefits of making more profit is that Yesenia can save enough money to fix the roof of her house and send her children to a better school.

column4: Buy fish in cash at a discount; Market products better with display case
column18: Mercis R., who was born in Esmeralda, Ecuador has lived in Guayaquil for 10 years. She is a 42 year-old single mother with 4 children, one of whom (7 years old) still lived in the household. Sra. R. has a fish business which she learned about from her parents. This long-time fish saleswoman of 15 years has been searching for a way to make greater profits so that she can provide for her children. Her daily routine is fairly normal; she wakes up at 4:00 am to buy the catch for the day at which point she brings the fish to her market and sells it until around 1:00 pm. If she does not sell all of her fish at the market, she takes it home with her and finishes selling it there, she says. Mercis wants to take out a $475 loan to buy fish in cash and choose from the freshest fish around. Also, she wants to improve the presentation of her business to market the products better and bring in more clients. Mercis wants lenders to know that she is a very industrious woman who wants nothing more than to have her business succeed so that she can provide a better life for her children.

column4: Sone Quarry Investment
column18:
A. Santina is an active member of Life in Africa. She currently works in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. Her salary combined with what her husband makes working in the stone quarry sustain their family.

Her family, like so many others, were forced to flee their home in Gulu in the North because of the war with the rebels. The headed to Kampala looking for a safe place to live and settled in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters. Their life was very hard at first but since joining LiA they have begun to hope and dream of a better life. They have begun to see possibilities instead of hopelessness.

Her husband knows the aggregate business very well since he works in it every day. There is much building going on in Kampala today so the demand for crushed stone is very high demand and very lucrative. The profit is almost double the costs of securing and crushing the stone. Their plan is to finance 12 trips to secure stone and waite for the customer within Kampala. There it will be crushed and sold netting them a tidy profit to continue on as well as adding to the family income.Santinas'aim is also to creat employment to the community arround Acholi quarters. To accomplish this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800.000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Therefore below is her break down:

Labor cost for making a trip full of aggregates is as stated below:

Stone extraction from the quarry 20,000/= x 12 = 240,000/=

Bringing out from the cave is 5000 x 12 = 60,000/=

Stone crashing by hand is 35,000/= x 12 =420,000/=

Loading cost 3000/= x 12 = 36,000/=

Others 44,000/=

Total = 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Talent discovery.

column4: Buying materials for finishing up building
column18:
N. Irene is an active member of Life in Africa. She currently works in the Invisible Children Bracelet project making bracelets and also dyeing the materials they use. She is a young wife and as yet does not have children. However, she hopes to and she wants to work now to secure a solid source of income so that her children will not have to know poverty.

Her parents have given her a four room house but it is not finished. She plans to rent out the rooms which will be a secure source of income but she knows that she will be able to earn more and keep her tenants longer if the house is complete. This will also provide better housing for the families who rent from her.

To complete this house she is seeking a loan in the amount of 700,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Her loan description is as below:

1 trips of sand @ shs. 80,000...........80,000/= Bricks 2000 @ shs.65...................130,000/= Wooden doors 2 @ shs.30,000............100,000/= Wooden windows 4 @ shs.40,000..........160,000/= Cement 5 bags @ shs.18,000............. 90,000/= Labour.................................100,000/= Transport.............................. 40,000/=

Total..................................700,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Education

column4: Buying materials for building family House
column18:
O. Christopher is an active member of Life in Africa. He joined almost 6 months ago because of his passion for crafts and this has earned him a good job as a bracelet maker for the Invisible Children Bracelet project. To suppliment what he earns he also works part time in the stone quarry.

He is 30 years old and was born in Northern Uganda. His childhood was stolen from him by the rebels when they attacked, brutally killing most of his relatives including his mother. He managed to survive but was forced to flee and he ended up in the displaced persons camp in Kampala known as the Acholi Quarters. Now he is married with four children of his own. They are all safe from rebel attacks but they still live in horrible conditions in the camp. His dream is to give his children what he has never had. A safe and permanent home where they can live in peace.

He has acquired a plot of land and he plans to build a home for his children. He has been saving and already has part of the money he will need. To add to his savings he is seeking a loan in the amount ot 800,000. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Cement 15 bags @ 18,000/=...... 270,000/= Transport â€“. ..................70,000/= Sand 2 trips................... 150,000/= Labour -....................... 150,000/= Bricks 3000 @ 65/=..............195,000/= Communication.................... 8,000/=

Total...........................843,000/=

O. has saved 100,000/= to help him complete this project. He promises , with utmost good faith to service this loan in a period of 12 months in sums of 80,000/= monthly.

WE Team to benefit: Talent Discovery

column4: Installation and buying airtime
column18:
Arnold K. is a very active member of Life in Africa. He joined in June of 2004 and works hard as a foreman at the center as well as a team leader for the art gallery. He also does sanding for the Invisible Children Bracelet project.

To support his family he has also opened a video library business. He believes he can expand and improve his business by offering additional services. A pay phone would be one of these services that is much needed by his clients who cannot afford to have their own phone. In addition he plans to also sell airtime cards for his clients who have cell phones. This will be a convenience for them since they will not have to move to so many different places to have their needs met. The sister is willing to work in this project at 30,000/= which Arnold has accepted to pay.

To accomplish this he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Phonebooth - @400,000 - 400,000 Airtime cards - 6 packets - @ 50,000 -300,000 Rent - 5months - @20,000 - 100,000

WE Team to benefit: Gallery promotion services

column4: Building family house
column18:
Peace Komugisha is a mutoro by tribe aged 45 years. She is a mother of four children though she is now living a single life in Kampala. Her husband passed away and she has no plans yet of returning to the village as her job now is the only means of supporting herself and family. Peace komugisha’s way of life in Kampala here was basically on local brew. She could make local brew, which is bused so much by the people living in the slums of Kampala. Much as this local brews consumed these city dwellers, peace got fed up with this type of business as she find that dealing with drunkard persons is a very hard task.

She joined life in Africa four months ago after she had dropped the local brew business and now working for the invisible children bracelet project as a bracelet maker. By the time Komugisha dropped the business, she had saved 200,000/= that she wishes to use for the construction of a family house in her village Mbarara. With the current job she has at Life in Africa her saving is now 400,000/= She looks at this loan scheme as an opportunity for her to own her dream house. With this regards she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/= that she is to repay in 12 months at a rate of 80000/= and below is her break down:

14 iron sheets of 32 gauge @ 10000 =. 140,000/=

3000bricks @ 50/= ……………………….150,000/=

15 bags of cement @ 18000……………….270,000/=

3 trips of sand @ 30000/=…………………90,000/=

Labor………………………………………..300,000/=

20 roofing timbers 4x3. @ 5000……………..100,000/=

One trip of aggregates ……………………….60,000/=

2 wooden doors @ 50000……………………100,000/=

2 wooden windows @ 15000…………………30,000/=

5kgs of nails @ 3000………………………….15,000/=

Total……………………………………………1,110,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Term: Talent discovery

column4: Buying building materials
column18:
O. Alfred is an active member of Life in Africa. He joined in September of 2005 and has worked very hard to provide for his family, which includes his wife and six children.

They were displaced by the war in Northern Uganda. He came from Gulu and has been completely separated from his other family members. He believes many of them are now dead and the others have not been able to be traced since the fled from the rebels. He and his family live in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters where they live in a small rented house.

He has acquired a plot of land from the King of Buganda who has mercy for these suffering people. He dreams of building a real home once again for his children and he has been working diligently towards that goal. He has managed to save 200,000 from his salary. Building this house will not only improve their living conditions and give them a permanant home, but it will free up the money they now have to pay for rent, which can be used to benefit the family. To complete this house he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

His budget is as below: Bricks 3000 @ 65/= 195,000/= Sand 2 trips @ 80,000/= 160,000/= Labor 150,000/= Iron 14 @10,000/= 140,000/= Transport 60,000/= Doors and windows 150,000/=

Total 855,000/=

WE Team to benefit:Talent discovery

column4: Start up a millet store
column18:
Judith T. is young woman from Kabale in Southwestern Uganga. She is a single mother of one child and is the sole support for herself and the child. She was never able to be educated in her village and she longed for a better life. So she left the village and moved to Kampala hoping to get an education and a good job.

Then her younger sister had to come and live with her and she had to give up on her own education. Instead, she has put all her efforts into keeping her sister and her child in school. This was very difficult since she had no steady income. Then she found Life in Africa where she now works in the Invisible Children bracelet project. The life has much improved but she knows she must do more to achieve all her goals.

Her plan is to open a business dealing with millet which is in high demand since it is a nutritious food source and is one of the staples of the Ugandan diet. She has already found a building to rent. She will employ one person to work the shop while she continues with her work at Life in Africa. She believes that the added income will make life much easier and will insure that her sister and child are able to finish school. For this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/= and she will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is her Budget:

Millet grain 20 bags @30,000/= 600,000/= Saucepans 2 units @10,000/= 20,000/= Transport 36,000/= Rent 70,000/=(5 months advance) Containers 2 units @30,000/= 60,000/= Cups 12 units @1,200/= 14,400/=

Total 800,400/= Judith will pay the loan back in 12 months at the rate of 80,000/= per months WE Team to benefit: Education

 WE Team to benefit: Adult Education

column4: Buying materials for roofing
column18:
S. Steven is an active and hard working member of Life in Africa. He is the proud father of one child and he is employed in the Invisible Children bracelet project as a sander.

Before coming to Life in Africa, he was a hawker. He walked miles each day selling small personal items like hair pins, soap, perfume, sunglasses and other items. The income he earned was what sustained his family but it was unreliable and on some days he earned nothing. This made life difficult. Now, his income is consistent and their lives have improved greatly.

Their biggest expense is the rent they pay for their small home. However, he does own a home that is not finished since it still lacks a roof. He has been saving to complete it. Once it is roofed, his family will be able to have a better life with the money they will be saving on rent and they will also have the pride of owning their own home. To complete this project he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/= and he will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

Below is his budget:

Iron sheets 30 units: 1 unit=11,000 330,000/= Labour 200,000/=

Total 530,000/= At present he has saved 30,000/= to help with the same. Steven will pay back this loan in full in 10 months.

WE Team to benefit: Craft Production

column4: Building a new house
column18:
C. Sopheng moved from Phnom Penh City to this newly populated area only one week ago. He is living with his wife and one grandson in a little shelter built quickly. He is requesting $300 to turn it into a proper house. He will but the materials and rent tools to perform the works with the help of a few relatives. He estimates they need only 2 days of hard labor to complete the task.

C. Sopheng is self employed as a moto-taxi and can make around $3 profit per day. His wife used to have a small laundry service business in Phnom Penh but now she doesn’t know what she can do.

C. Sopheng has a plan for the future. When this new village will be connected to basic facilities such as water and electricity, he will launch a business of producing and selling ice cream. “I don’t know exactly how to produce it, but I can learn from friends”, he said.

column4: Building a new house
column18:
H. Sokhorn is requesting a $500 loan to build a proper house in the plot she was recently allocated by the government in Phnom Penh far suburbs. H. Sokhorn is not employed; she stays at home and takes care of her children, while her husband is self-employed as a mason. He learnt his skill when employed by a Chinese company, which ceased its activities 4 years ago. He sustains his family with around $5 daily but his income is not steady. He has to propose competitive bids to be in charge of the works, but as he is a gifted worker, he is not worrying about unemployment.

With the $500, H. Sokrom will purchase materials and her husband will built the house in addition to his casual workload.

Hom Sokhorn would like to start a business of catering for the neighborhood, if the village becomes more populated.

column4: Building a new house
column18:
Seng Siengdy is a single mother living with her six children, two of them already grown and employed in sewing and cement factories and three others going to school.

Seng Siengdy was granted a small plot of land after being displaced from Phnom Penh to this new village. As her neighbors, Seng Siengdy would like to build a house very soon and she requested $500 to have the works performed. If everything goes smoothly, she expects her house to be built in 1 week only, considering she will hire 3 workers full-time.

Seng Siengdy used to have a small business in town. She was selling ice for the small restaurant on the streets. She would like to start again but the village is not yet connected to the power grid and the demand for ice is very low, as there is not yet a restaurant. The family is confident about repaying the loans on the children’s salaries, which is $220 cumulated per month. “This won’t be easy, but the house is worth it”, she said.

column4: Building a new house
column18:
S. Dara is married and father of three children, all of them are go to school in Phnom Penh city. He is self-employed as a moto-taxi driver and makes around 15,000 Riel every day. His wife is running a very special business, as she sells Ants’ Eggs to a few traditional restaurants of the City. Ants’ Eggs are very scarce in Phnom Penh but S. Dara’s wife has good connections with collectors from the provinces and she can sell for 150,000 Riel ($37.5) daily with a margin of around 40%.

S. Dara already spent $900 of his personal savings on the roof and the walls of his new house but he needs an additional $500 to finish it. He will perform most of the building operations by himself and hopes to finish it very soon.

After building the house, S. Dara is considering resuming his career as a government officer he interrupted 7 years ago for familial obligations.

column4: Building a new house
column18:
S. Som At is married and mother of 6 children, who are between 30 and 12 years old. She is not employed but still very busy with taking care of her children and grandchildren. Her husband is a moto-taxi, and brings two of their children to school in the city every morning.

S. Som At moved to this new place with her family only 12 days ago. All of them are still camping until their new house is built. That is why S. Som At contacted CREDIT. She needs a $500 loan to rent the skilled labor force ($250 for 1 week) and purchase the materials (another $250). S. Som At is saving money on the materials because she moved with the remains of her previous house. She already has wood and zinc for the roof.

When the house is finished, S. Som At is planning to start a business in the community. “With my next loan”, she said.

column4: Dorah would like to renovate her granary which allows rodents and leaking thus destroying her farm produce.
column18:
Dora M. is 60 years old, married with 10 children. Out of the ten children 8 are independent while 2 still go to school.

Dorah is a farmer, grows and sells maize, Potatoes, Beans, coffee, and sells milk too.

She started this business 20 years ago and it has assisted her to educate all her children.

Her business makes at least USD 125 per month and this assists her to pay school fees for her 2 children and general household requirements. The poor storage facility forces her to sell at cheap prices whereas if she had improved facility, she would be storing her produce until the prices are relatively high.

column4: Jane wants to improve her farming by buying fodder for her dairy cow, buy fertilizer and agro chemicals for her cabbages to keep high quality vegetables.
column18: Jane is 56 years old, married with 1 child.  She has been a member of Kabuta Ladies in Action since 2001. The group runs a group revolving fund where she received a loan of USD100 in 2003 fortunately paid in time. Her first loan helped her to buy pesticides for her coffee which at the end of the season she sold and made a profit of USD200. She grows and sells tea leaves, cabbages, and potatoes. In addition to vegetables, Jane also sells milk in Gakira which gives her USD 30 as profit in a month.

column4: Joyce wants to pay school fees for her children because her business’s cash flow is low but can raise the money in three months.
column18:
Joyce is a widow aged 50 years with 6 children. Single handedly, she has been able to educate her children where one is in secondary school while three are in college and two have finished college but not yet employed.

She is an active member of Anglican Church of Kenya where she is a choir member. Also she is a member of Kabuta Ladies in Action a community based organization whose activities aim at uplifting and promoting income generating activities at house hold level.

Joyce is a farmer and grows maize, beans, coffee, Potatoes and Vegetables both for sale and home consumption. More so, she sells milk which gives her about USD 10 per month.

column4: Lois would like to improve her embroidery work by buying maasai materials.
Margaret wants to start selling other food stuffs such as yellow bananas, mangoes, green pepper, and onions.
column18: Margaret is 56 years old, married and all her children are independent. Unfortunately, one of her daughters passed away and left three children. Margaret takes care of the three children. Two are in primary school while the oldest one assists her to run the business. She is working hard to educate them up to at least college level. She set her business near the busiest bus stage of Rongai. Her business is located near the bus stop and therefore makes a lot of sales in the evening when the residents going back home from work. However, in the morning she supplies to those who roastboil maize along the roadside. She buys fresh maize from various markets; Wakulima, Kiserian and Kadisi.

column4: Monica wants to buy Cosmetics, Fashionable clothes and some plastic seats for her trainees to use.
column18:
Monica is married with 2 children. She is trained as a hair dresser and has located her business in a very busy area of Rongai centre. Monica joined WEEC program in 2003 and has received training on Group leadership, Basic business skills, and Customer care.

 Monica wants to make optimum use of her room. She therefore wants to add cosmetics, and also buy stock of the current attires that are fashionable for the youth. When she has many customers, Monica hires trained hairdressers and pays them on commission basis. She is also preparing to start training those who want to become hairdressers but can’t afford to pay for fulltime hairdressing course.

column4: Ruth wants to include other foodstuffs such as cassava, arrow roots, yams and Irish potatoes.
column18:
Ruth is a single mother and 50 years old. Her husband married another wife when Ruth failed to get many children. In 2003 she started a small business of selling green maize. She moved from house to house especially in parklands area selling. This work was very tedious and she decided to get a permanent stall in Rongai. From her proceeds she managed to buy a small plot where she settled with her son.

Ruth has set her business at the busy Tuesso stage Ongata Rongai. Her main customers are the casual workers who work in stone quarries at Rimpa, Gataka and those that live in Kware slum area. They pay her on a weekly basis as they get their wages. She intends to stock more items to cater for their demand. She also supplies the people who roast maize on the roadsides. Ruth`s average sales is USD 7 per day.

column4: Rose would like to purchase a variety of fruits to increase her customer base.
Purchase of an Electrical Pump and a Reservior Tank
column18: Amina is married with three children.She lives in the outskirts of Dar es Salaam where there is no public water service system.Residents depends on shallow wells which are not covered as the main source of water for domestic use. Outbreak of waterborne deseases like diarrhoea and cholera is common.Amina through her savings managed to drill a shallow well and covered it with a slab made of cement.Her business is not yet operational because she is short of funds of buying reservior tank and an electrical pump.She needs an additional capital of USD 750 so as to buy an Electrical pump and a Tank to effectivelly run her business.The tank will be used as a distribution and a water treatment point.The business would make her improve her livelihood but more important provide a valuable water service to the community.

column4: WORKING CAPITAL
column18: Leonard is married with three children. He lives in Kiwalani area in Dar es Salaam. He sells vegetables and fruits near his residence. He buys fresh produce of fruits and vegetables from nearby villages for resale at a small profit. The business has been his main source of livelihood for the past ten years. The business has not grown because he has to make a balance between business and family needs. The proposed loan will assist Leonard to expand his business by adding new products. The amount needed to expand his business is US$ 950. If his business is expanded, he will be able to meet the challenge of paying school fees for his child who is expected to start secondary education. The business provides a source of employment for his wife too.

column4: Working  Capital
column18: M. lives in Vituka area in Dar es Salaam. He owns a shop selling different consumable items. He aims at increasing the stock of soft drinks.  Soft drinks have high turnover in his shop. The demand of soft drinks in Dar es Salaam is high because of the weather, it is hot through out the year. The profit margin of soft drinks, mainly Pepsi cola are high if one a retailer buys more than 50 crates at a time. The loan requested will enable M. to meet the needs of a profitable level of purchase of stocks. He is asking for a loan of US$ 950.

column4: Working capital
column18: S. is married with four children. He lives in Kiwalani area in Dar es Salaam. He owns a shop near his residence. He sells different items in his shop. He recently realized high demand for sewing and tailoring supplies. With his savings he managed to stock few of these sewing materials. He cannot meet the demand for these items due to insufficient working capital. He is in need of additional capital of USD 950 to run this new line of business effectively.

column4: Building a new house for his family
column18:
T. Eorn and his family used to live in Phnom Penh city, near to a pagoda. They moved 12 days ago because the Cambodian government granted them a piece of land in this new village, around 25 kilometers away from the center of the city.

T. Eorn is married and lives with his wife and 5 children. His two eldest daughters are already working in a factory, making $45 per month, while two of his children are still going to school and two stay with her wife at home. He is employed by the government and earns $120 monthly.

T. Earn requested $500 to build a house for his family to live properly. He stressed their need to have toilets installed in her house. The village is not yet connected to the power and the water grids but she expect this to be done soon. When her loan will be disbursed, T. Eorn will purchase raw materials and hire two people for three weeks, until the works are completed.

“This new house is a real chance for the 7 of us”, she said, “because living outside the city is good for our health and safer for our children”.

column4: Housing improvement
column18:
M. Sokni is a moto-taxi in Phnom Penh. He moved in this new village from downtown a couple of weeks ago and is now riding the 25 kilometers back and forth everyday for a net profit of 10,000 Riel ($2.5).

His wife is employed in a sewing factory in Phnom Penh and M. also transports her to her workplace and back home at night. Her salary is about $70 per month.

With the $500 he requested, Sokni would like to upgrade the house he built in a hurry when the couple was granted this piece of land. He is to buy materials and tools but also filling land to elevate the ground floor of the house. This improvement is critical as the rainy months already started.  

Sokni expects to be able to perform these improvements by himself in two weeks time. If there is still a little money left at the end, he would like to open a shop in front of his house and sell grocery and coffee to the people of the community.

column4: Improving the house
column18:
I. Somoul is living with her grown son in a quickly built and precarious shelter in a new village around 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They moved in two weeks ago and have felt a critical need for housing improvement since their arrival. I. Somoul herself requested a $300 loan but she trusts her son to manage everything related to the works. He explained us he is going to buy for $250 of materials such as sand, cement, wood and zinc and hire two people from the community for 100,000 Riel ($25) for 1 week. He truly believes the works can be completed one single week after receiving the money from CREDIT.

I. Somoul is concerned about repaying her loan. She is self-employed and sells fruits and vegetable in a Market in Phnom Penh. She gets up early morning with her son and together they go to buy their fruits and vegetables at 4 am. She usually finishes at 5pm. She can make 20,000 Riel ($5) profit every day, while her son is making 10,000 Riel from taxi fares.

column4: Finish to build his house
column18:
W. Kaemorak is married and lives with his wife and three children in the house they built quickly after moving into their new village. He started the works two weeks ago but needs additional funds to complete the improvement he planed. He is doing everything alone, “by my own” he said in English.

W. Kaemorak speaks a little English. He learnt when driving foreigners on his moto-taxi. He would like to learn more but his wife say he is too old now. “English is for fresh brains”, she said. Their two youngest children, 14 and 5 years old, are going to school six days a week.

As for the family resources, the moto taxi breeds around 12,000 Riel ($3) per day. Kaemorak’s wife can make around 10,000 Riel ($2.5) in sewing trousers and repairing clothes on her machine at home. The family eldest son is employed as a security guard in a night club in Phnom Penh. He makes $80 per month and works at night.

column4: Building a brand new house
column18:
P. Sa Hel and his brother are building a brand new house in a new village from scratch. This will take a full month and cost around $1,000, but P. Sa Hel and his wife have savings and are only requesting a $500 loan. This is a price worth paying for this couple to have their own house.

P. Sa Hel is a moto-taxi and makes around 12,000 Riel ($3) a day. His wife is employed in a shop in Phnom Penh. She sells mobile phones and earns around 60,000 Riel per day ($15). They are very confident in repaying this loan on time.

P. Sa Hel is very happy with the situation. “I like this new place”, he said, “because there is fresh air”. “The place is not for sale”, he added, “we will raise our family here!”

column4: Purchase of Water Tank
column18: Elizabeth is married with four children. She lives in Kijichi area in Dar es Salaam. The area has no reliable water supply. By the help of her husband and her own savings she managed to buy a water tank and an electric pump. The current size of the tank is not sufficient to meet demand of water from residents.  No public water system exist in the area. Erratic power supply which is experienced by all residents in Dar es Salaam also justifies the need for an additional storage tank and its accessories.  The additional tank will also provide an additional facility for treatment of water ready for domestic use. The project has a great value to the community as it provides a valuable resource need by each households and reduces incidences of water borne diseases.

column4: To increase stock of used clothes.
To increase the stock of firewood for the business.
To buy more fabrics.
To buy and sell more poultry.
To increase the stock the stock of produce.
To increase the stock of pharmacy
To increase stock of poultry breed.
To add more stock in the secretarial bereau.
To add more stock in secretarial work
To increase on stock of Timber.
To add more stock in the business of clothes and shoes.
Sunanda will purchase an improved sewing machine to stitch more clothes
column18:
Ms.Sunanada K. - age 18 - is a spinster .She stays with her family of 5. She is educated up to 7th class is living in her small village called Sanganatti in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India. Now she is engaged in tailoring with a single sewing machine. She earns  Rs.30/- per day. She wants to purchase a improved sewing machine with which she will be able to stitch more cloths to increase her daily income to Rs.50/- to Rs.60/- per day.  To purchase this sewing machine she requires a loan amount of Rs.3000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 1 years and installment will paid once in every 6 month. 

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US  dollar

column4: Purchasing a buffalo
column18:
Mr.Siddaling P. – handicapped - aged 19 years is bachelor staying with his 5 family members. He was illliterate but is now able to read and write with the help of night school. He lives in a small village called Marapur in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India. He now does tailoring work in the village for Rs.50/- day. He would like to shift to dairy business by purchase one she buffalo. By rearing this buffalo he will be able to get about 12-15 liters milk per day and by which he will be able to earn an amount of Rs.125/- to Rs.150/- per day with a net profit of Rs.75/- to Rs.100/- per day. To purchase buffalo he requires a loan amount of Rs.15000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 2 years and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

column4: Purchasing a she-buffalo
column18:
Ms.Renukavva Y.M. - aged 30 years, has two daughters. She was ill literate and now able to read and write by attending night school in her small village called Madabhavi in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India.  Now she is working as a farm labor for Rs.40/- day. She would like to purchase one she buffalo. By rearing this buffalo she will be able to get about 12-15 liters milk per day and by which she will be able to earn an amount of Rs.125/- to Rs.150/- per day with a net profit of Rs.75/- to Rs.100/- per day. To by this she bufellow she requires a loan amount of Rs.15000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 2 years and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

column4: To hire 2 additional labourers
column18:
Ms. Sunita S.P. - aged 28  is  married and has 4 children. She was educated up to 7th class. She is living in her village called Saidapur in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India. Now she is engaged in small-scale leather business by which she is earning an amount of Rs.35/- per day. She purchases raw leather and after fine finish she supplies the same to foot wears makers. Now she would like to expand her business by employing one or two woman labourers. To expand her business she requires a loan amount of Rs.10000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 1 year and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

column4: She would like to buy a dairy cow that can give her 20 litres per day.
column18:
Mary Warua is 62 years old, married with 6 children, 2 of them still live with her and provides every thing.

Mary has been selling used clothes for the last seven years. The business has been performing very well because these items are not only cheap but also affordable by many people. This gives her a high profit margin and keeps her pushing forward. She also grows coffee on a small scale and keeps a dairy cow. There is improvement in milk prices and this is encouraging her to buy another cow, which can give about 20 litres per day.

column4: Lucy wants to buy a diary cow to supplement her income.
column18:
Lucy is 48 yrs old a widow and has 5 children. Of these children, two are in secondary school; two in primary school while the other is working.

Lucy has been carrying out farming activities for 22 years, and this provides for her household necessities. Her coffee plantation is about three hectares and has another hectare where she grows fodder and seasonal crops. Due to low prices of coffee in the whole country, she has been concentrating on dairy farming. At least she earns about USD 70 per month.

column4: She intends to buy a high breed dairy cow that will produce aleast 18 litters of milk per day.
column18:
Sylvia is 50 years old married with 4 children, two of them are independent and two still in college and secondary school.

She has been running a small shop for the last 8 years, realizing a net income of approximately USD 100 per month. She has also a small coffee farm, which brings in some income seasonally.However, this is not enough to sustain her family requirements thus, need for extra source of income.

column4: She wants to replace in phases her current dairy cows which on average produce 8 litters of milk per day with hybrid cows that can give 15 litres per day.
column18:
Jane is 53 years old a widow with 5 children. Two are in a local technical college and one in High School.

Jane has been in farming for 28 years and it’s from farming that she has been able to educate her children. She has 400 trees of coffee on a three-hectare piece of land and 2 Dairy cows, which in aggregate brings a net income of USD100 per month.

column4: Adonijo wants to buy a dairy cow so as to improve her daily income from the sell of milk.
column18:
Adonijo is 49 years old married with 5 children; two are in a technical college while the other one is in High School.

She has been in horticulture farming for more than 20 years and has a good customer base of institutions such as schools and local hotels.

The loan applied for of $600 is intended to diversify her area of farming to include dairy farming. Her objective is to take advantage of this group of dairy farmers she joined recently because they will be buying animal feeds and drugs as a group which is cheaper than when you are alone.

column4: Income from vegetables is not enough and thus she wants also to start selling milk, which is easy to market and does not take a lot of time.
column18:
Mary W. is 53 years old widow with 6 children, one in college, two in High school and others in primary school.

She grows vegetables on a 2-hectare piece of land. She has been selling vegetables for more than 5 years. Demand for her vegetables grows day by day because the society is now aware of the values in vegetables due to home development seminars chairperson of her group and the campaign by the government about health living.

column4: She intends to purchase a hybrid dairy cow, which can produce a lot of milk.
column18:
Jane M. is 56 years old, married with 5 children. Three of her children are independent while the others are in a technical college.

Jane has been running her shop for more than 18 years, realizing a net income of approximately $180 per month. She also has a small farm from which she gets additional income and food for her family.

As a member of a dairy farming group, she will greatly increase her income given that she has all other necessary resources.

column4: She would like to buy a dairy cow, which would be producing approximately 20 litters of milk per day.
column18:
Jane K. is 49 years old married with 5 children, 3 in college and 2 in High school.

For approximately 18 years, Jane has been keeping poultry and it has been her sole source of income. She always keeps 600 broilers every crop and she constantly supplies to her customers in Kangema Town. She also has two dairy cows each producing roughly 10 litters of milk. Annually she realizes a gross income that ranges between $ 400 and $ 500 per month.

column4: Refrescos, hielo, venta de comida
column18:
My first loan I invested in only clothing. It was for L500.00. The second loan I used for plastics and I earned a profit. With the third loan I was awarded L700.00 and I bought my refigerator and I began to sell what I am selling at present.

With my individual credit, I am able to sell more because I have invested in my business and with the earnings I have recieved, I can better my home. Thank you to the Adelante Foundation.

Loan Use: Sodas, ice, food storage/display to sell in shop

Original Description in Spanish: Mi primer prestamo lo inverti en ropa solo fueron L500.00 pero algo es algo. El segundo en plastico y fui obteniendo ganancia. Me prestara L700.00 con el tercer prestamo y compre mi refrigeradora y empese a vender lo que vendo ahora. 

Con mi credito individual, vendo mas porque lo he invertido en mi negocio y con las ganacias he podido hacerle mejora ma mi casa. Gracias a Fundacion Adelante.

column4: Cria de cerdo, destoso de cerdo, venta de comidas, refrescos
column18:
With my first loan of L500.00, I bought eggs, one pig, sodas and with the earnings I have invested in the betterment of my home. My home used to be old and dilapitated.

With my individual loan I have bought more pigs, sodas and foods. With my earnings that I have made divisions (for rooms) that are made of cement. Also, I am the educator of my assembly.

Loan use: Caring for the pigs, butchering of the pigs, food storage display to sell in shop, sodas.

Original Description in Spanish: Con mi primer prestamo de L500.00 compro huevos, un cerdo, y refrescos y las ganacias los invertio mejorar la casa, mi cas era manaca y cana brava.

Con mi prestamo individual he comprado mas cerdos, refrescos y comidas. Con las ganacias he hecho los divisiones de mi casa que ahora es de cemento. Tambien, soy la educadora de mi asemblea.

column4: Assorted items - general retail
column18: My name is Maria Concepcion A. M., but they call me Concha.  I am 30 Years old and I have 1 daughter who is 14.  I have been with Adelante for 1 ½ years and am on my third loan.   I had a small business before, but it was very small and didn’t make much money.  Now I have bought a microwave, some furniture and a lot of other things for my house with the earnings from my business.  I have also been able to buy things for my daughter that I couldn’t before like new clothes, shoes, and now I am able to send her to highschool.  I wouldn’t be where I am today without the loans and education from Adelante.  For example we recently had a business planning lecture that talked about planning enough time for family and business and for me that was very useful.  I have also learned a lot about how to keep a record of my business – to record sales and inventory so that I can grow my business.
