In the next year or two I would like to be able to buy my own house, continue to grow my business and continue to learn.I had very little when I started but I had a small business – it wasn’t until my first loan with Adelante that I have been able to really make a business.With the education lessons I know how to grow inventory I even bought a freezer to increase the products to sell and I will increase my sales by notating what sells.  I have recommended several women to Adelante and tell them that they will be given money and knowledge to start their own business.  But I also tell them that they need to be ready to work and if they are then they can have a business like just like mine.

column4: Building a family house
column18:
My name is P. Keefa and a married man with four children. I joined life in Africa in january and also work with the Invisible children's bracelet project as a sander. From the wages makes, he supports and maintain them all. I also live in rented house and the money he payS for rent is really my biggest expense and makes life very difficult. I would really dream of having a house of my own. I already have a good sized piece of land on which to build my own house. This house means total security to my children and wife ven when am gone from this world. This is why am seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/= to help me achieve this dream. He is ready to pay this loan within 10 months. Loan use: Build family house

Loan term: 10 months

Loan payment; 80,000/=

Below is his budget:

Labour 100,000/= Cement 9 bags @ 17,000 153,000/= Nails 20,000/= Bricks 5,000 @45/= 225,000/= Timbers 12 @ 500/= 6,000/= iron sheets 18pcs @11,000 198,000/= Sand 3 trips 30,000/= Transport 3 trips 30,000/= Water 30,000/= Communication 8,000/=

Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Education

column4: Expanding food store
column18:
Rose M. is a very wonderful lady who joined Life in Africa early this year. She is a widow with 8 children. Her husband died from a motor accident in 2001. She is very skilled in handcrafts and makes such beautiful crafts like ladies bags, scarves, mats, baskets, beads, etc. She is currently renting a house in Nsambya, a suburb of Kampala. She earns her living and supports her family through earnings from the bracelet project at LiA and wholesale store near her place of residence that deals with foodstuffs like beans, cowpeas, maize and soyabeans. She needs to expand this business so as to be able to maintain her children in school, pay the house rent, feeding and clothing plus medicare. She is now seeking aloan in the amount of 800,000/= to expand this business and get more profits and increase her savings so that infuture, she can begin to build her own house so as to get rid of this rent business because, rent actually uses much more money that anything else in her life. These savings also would help with the ever increasing school fees for the children. Rose will be able to pay back this loan in 10 months. Below is her budget:

Beans 12 bags 60,000 - 720,000 Transport 84,000

Total 804,000

Loan use: e Expand Wholesale Food Store

Loan term: 10 months

Loan repayment: 80,000/= per month

WE Team to benefit: Education

column4: Expanding Family House
column18:
Faustino O. is a member of Life in Africa and a family man too. He has lived through thick and thin to support his family. He left the stone Quarrying business to his wife and started working with the invisible bracelet project as a bracelet producer and because of his articulate and concise approach to issues, Faustino was entrusted with quality control in the invisible children Bracelet campaign that is in partnership with Life in Africa. With his visionary acumen, he seeks to expand his house by constructing two more rooms for rent, which will help him to save more money to square his family bills.

Faustino has already saved 250,000 and to to meet his expectations of expansion he needs a loan of 800,000 UGX and he comfortably believes he will service the loan over a period of 10 months in premium sums of 80,000 from his monthly IC salary and the stone business itself.

His budget is as follows:

Bricks 4000 @ Ushs.60 = 240,000 Iron Sheets 24pcs @Ushs. 11,000 = 264,000 Bags of Cement 10Pkts @Ushs.18500 = 185,000 Timber @Ushs. 60,000 Transport @Ushs. 40,000 Water @ Ushs.11, 000 Labour 250,000 Total Ushs. 1,050,000

WE Team to benefit:Member Services

column4: Purchasing a sewing machine and Tie & Dye Fabrics.
column18:
Esther T. is a mother of three, Esther lives with her husband who is a businessman. She joined Life in Africa in October 2004. She is a very talented designer especially gifted with tie and dye and, also makes awesome crafts. Her tie and dye fabrics are much sought after especillay by African women. Esther also works at Life in Africa with the invisible children bracelet project as a bracelet producer. she does earn an income that can help with the house expenses. Esther's challenge is that after making her tie and dye products, she needs to ask some one with a sewing machine to help her sew her beautiful into garments so she can put them up for sale. She then has to pay for this service by the sewing machine owner. If only she had her own machine, she would be producing lots good quality garments. This is the reason why she now seeks a loan in the amount of 800,000/= so she can have her own machine and buy materials to do this work without her having to pay for the service. This will also enable her to do her work much faster and more attention will be paid to it. Esther will be able to pay back this money in 12 months. Below is her budget:

Sewing machine 400,000/= Material cloth 200,000/= Rent 150,000/= Contingencies 50,000/= Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Education

column4: BUying a cow and building a cow-house
column18:
C. Monyrort is a farmer. He is living with his wife, three children and two younger brothers in a village near to Phnom Penh. He is growing rice and vegetables and owns 4 cows, which are very useful to plough his parcels of land. When the cows are too old to work, he sells them for their meat. He is rather experienced in raising cows and would like to turn this activity into a profitable business. His wife is running her own business, selling water spinach, she can make $5 per day.

C. Monyrort is requesting a $1,000 loan to buy an additional cow and to build a cow-house to shelter these precious animals. The cow will cost him between $500 and $700 while the materials (cement, wood and zinc mainly) for building the cow-house are worth $500. In addition to performing the works by himself, Monyrort will probably invest some of his own savings in the business too. The cow-house will be big enough for at least 10 animals and Monyrort might well buy one more with his next CREDIT loans.

column4: Build a small shop in front of the factories
column18:
K. Chanthon has born ten children, six of them are still living with her. She is a widow and supports her family with a small business she is running with her four grown children. They sell dry food in front of the numerous factories in this area. The five of them can sell for 160,000 Riel ($40) per day, out of which 40,000 Riel ($10) profit.

K. Chanthon wants to start a new business. Her plan is to open a real shop in front of a factory. She could sell clothes, spices and even more…

She needs $500 to have the shop built and would like to purchase for $500 stock. She will probably also invest her own savings.

K. Chanthon is confident because she knows that two of her grown sons, who are employed in factories, would help her if anything wrong happened. If this business is successful, she is already considering another one, which would be building a house to rent it.

column4: purchasing stock
column18:
K. Kontia is living in Phnom Penh city, with her husband and three children. She is running a small grocery shop in front of her house and sells various products to the people in the neighborhood. Kontia has sweet and toys for children but also soap and noodles for their parents, and almost everything necessary for the household.

She started the business 3 months ago and invested $400 of her own money already. She is now requesting $600 to increase her stocks and offer more products. She confident, the business is good so far, but she needs additional running capital.

For the moment, she is she can sell for 150,000 Riel ($37.5) everyday, and make 20,000 Riel ($5) on the shop but she expects better as the number of clients is increasing. With the 20,000 Riel her husband earns as a moto-taxi, K. Kontia can support her family. She is very proud that her eldest son and daughter are going to school. She would like to be able to send the last one also very soon.

column4: She would like to pay School fees for her child who is in her final year doing CPA(K).
column18: Damaris is married with 4 children and her last born is in college. She is a retired civil servant and now her major source of income is from the sale of milk from two cows. Her last born is in her final year at Shine College doing Certified Public Accountants stage 3, she is privately sponsored and this requires a lot of money. Currently she sells 10 litres per day which gives her USD 4 a day. Damaris’ income is very low to pay for her child school fees and thus need to access a loan which will be paid in installments on a monthly basis. This would be easier for her because her business will not be affected and her cash flow will remain stable.

column4: She would like to buy a welding machine.
column18: Patricia is 27 years old, married with one child who is attending nursery school. She has been a treasurer of a savings and credit group called Mary Gorret Kiangunyi for the last four years. She started her business in 1998 with only one piece of welding machine and one person. Currently, she has two welding machines and employs four people. She is planning to open up another branch in Nairobi where the demand for metal works is relatively high. Her average sales per month range from USD 300 toUSD500. She expects to increase her sales when she gets another machine from USD 500 to at least USD 700.

column4: She intends to buy one more cow to increase milk production as well as sales.
column18:
Jane is 48 years old and a teacher by profession. She is married with 6 children; three of them are in primary school, 1 in college and the other in secondary school.  She has a dairy cow and also grows maize, beans, Potatoes & Vegetables for sale as well as for home consumption. Her cow produces 8 litres per day, therefore she earns USD2.35. In addition to earnings from milk, she sells vegetables and she gets USD220 per month. \r\n

Maize being the main food for Kenyans, there is market for maize in whichever form it is. Also her milk has ready market because she supplies her fellow teachers.

column4: The business is still under capitalized and therefore she wants to buy more of rice, sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, soap, salt and bread.
column18: Regina is 48 Years of age, married with 3 children. She is primary school teacher. The salary from teaching service was not enough to cater for her home expenses thus; she decided to start up a small retail shop in April 2006 this year to supplement her salary. The business is progressing and she is earning USD 73 per month. The business is situated in Githurai a busy market, this call for a well stocked shop in order to attract customers.

column4: Mary would like to increase the supply of cakes and to buy more shoes.
column18: Mary is 40 years of age married with 4 children. Three of her children are in primary school and the other one in secondary school.She has a small bakery and supplies cakes to small retail shops in Kandara, Kenol, Thika and some parts of Nairobi. In addition to the cakes business, she also has a small shop where she sells ladies shoes. From her businesses she is able to get about $142 per month and this alone can not sustain her family. She is good at choosing ladies shoes because they don’t take a lot of time on the shelves and it makes her business grow. Considering the demand of her cakes, she is certain that if she increases quantity supplied per day then, she will start climbing the ladder to financial sustainability.

column4: She is to construct a shed for her cows and improve on cattle feeds so as to increase milk production.
column18: Agnes is 53 Years old, married with 2 children all in college. She is a teacher by profession and also a farmer. She has 2 dairy cows; they produce 10 litres of milk thus, she earns USD 3 per day. The business has been successful due to the ready market of fresh milk which she sells to the neighboring homes. She wants to start selling shoes to supplement income from milk and her teaching salary. With all income inflows, she believes the expenses of her family will be managed and raise her standard of living.

column4: Sarah would like to pay school fees for her children.
She would like to boost her business by buying latest ladies shoes and clothes.
Elizabeth would like to improve on the quality of her out put by planting hybrid crops which have high yield thus; she wants to buy hybrid seeds.
Alice wants to buy first class used clothes to sell with the new clothes she makes.
Susan wants to buy cosmetics in large quantities to enjoy economies of scale and have a constant supply to her clients.
column18: Susan started her business in 1986 by selling cosmetics in Nairobi Gikomba Market. She is 34years old, married with 4 children. She is a member of Wamama Development a church founded group which mobilizes Women to startup economic activities. She has a good clientele base that gives her courage to keep moving forward. Her customers include Salons, Small retail shops and to a small extent Individuals. Her monthly gross sales rage from USD735-880. Her target is to increase her sales to at least USD 1000 per month and this can only be done if she gets extra funding.

column4: Kemunto wants to increase her capital base in order to have the capacity of buying in bulk from Mombasa where bales of shoes are relatively cheaper.
column18: K. is married with 2 children and she is 26 years old. She started her business in 2002. She buys bales of used shoes from Mombasa and Nairobi then, sells to retailers. She sells 4 bales per day and makes profit of about USD 100-170. However, this will increase when all items are bought from Mombasa. She will be earning about USD200 per day.

column4: She would like to buy a variety of African attire such that clients can have a variety to choose from.
column18: Mary is 34 years of age and has one child. She started her business in 2003 by selling food stuffs. As business grew, she started buying vitenge (African Attire) from Tanzania selling them in Nairobi. Over the years, the business has been growing and it has contributed greatly to providing School fees for her siblings as well as providing the basic necessities at home.

column4: : She would like to buy more materials for uniforms and house hold items to easily supply her customers.
column18: Jacinta is married with 1 child. After leaving college, she got a small job at Kware, Rongai and from the little savings she made, she bought her own sowing machine and started off her own work. She started her business in 1996. She gets tenders from schools for making uniforms ie dresses, shirts and shorts. The business has grown over the years and she bought other machines to coup up with the increasing demand.

column4: Compra de cemento, arena, herramientas como pala, carreta de mano y otros
column18:
My name is Mariza.  I have been making cinder blocks for 4 years, that are used in the construction of buildings, houses, walls.  I have a great clientele, especially some iron workers in my city.  The generated income from this activity help me fulfill family and business commitments.  I am experienced in this business and due to the high demand, I employ a few young people to help manufacture the cinder blocks.

[Note from Kiva:  The above is Kiva staff member's transalation of the below text -- using Google translator and working knowledge of Spanish based off of 4 years high school Spanish, a very long time ago!  Apologies for any errors or omissions.]

Mi nombre es Maritza tengo cuatro años de dedicarme a la elaboracion de Bloques, que se usan para construccion de edificios, casas, muros, ya tengo una buena clientela especialmente algunas ferreterias de mi ciudad, las ganacias que me genera esta actividad son bastantes buenas ya que me ayudan a cumplir con los compromisos familiares y del negocio. Este negocio es familiar y debido a la demanda que tengo de pedidos he contratado a otros jovenes quienes nos ayudan para la fabricacion de los bloques.

column4: Compra de pan, huevos, harina, manteca, refrescos, churros, condimentos y otros
column18:
I have had my grocery store for five years, it is visited by neighbors as well as people from other communities. I am interested in attending my clientel well, for which they always treat me with respect. The earnings help me to contribute with the expenses of food and education of my two children so that they finish elementary school.

Loan Use: Buying bread, eggs, flour, butter, drinks, churros, condiments and others 

Tengo cinco años de tener mi pulperia, la cual es visitada por vecinos y otras personas de otras comunidades, me interesa atender bien a mis clientes por lo que siempre les doy un trato personalizado. Las ganacias me ayudan a contribuir con los gastos de almientacion y educacion de mis dos hijos para que finalicen su primaria.

column4: Compra de cemento, arena, tornillos, clavos, toma corrientes, focos, lamparas y otros.
column18:
I have been working for one year in my hardware store, it is a family run business, in which my two children and other youths that I have contracted, attend to my clients. I have a loyal clientel, since, for the price, I make contracts with the houses being constructed and the builders in my city. This activity generates enough (income) to support my family.

Loan Use: Cement, sand, screws, nails, sockets, floodlights, lamps and other 

Tengo un año de tener mi ferreteria, este es un negocio familiar en el que me ayudan mis dos hijos y otros jovenes que he contratado para atender a mis clientes, tengo clientela fija, ya que por los precios hago contratos con las casas constructoras y albañiles en mi ciudad. Esta actividad me genera lo suficiente para apoyar a mi familia.
